PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;

3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.

PETITION.TITLE: Rejection of Increase in Leaded Petrol Tax

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The 1993 Federal Budget announced by the Keating Labor Government to increase the excise on leaded fuel by 10 cents per litre,

PETITION.PARA: is a selective, discriminatory tax on owners of older cars;
discriminates against poorer people and country people who own most of these older cars;
will make it more difficult for people to save to purchase newer, more fuel efficient, less-polluting vehicles;
is therefore counter-productive to reducing lead pollution in the air.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject this increase in fuel excise and that the Senate will urge the Government to take initiatives to reduce the cost of manufacturing cars in Australia, thereby making new cars cheaper to buy.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

1.Users of off-road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel;
2.We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3.This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: DETERMINATION INS 21/1993 MADE UNDER S.4(1)(DD) OF THE NATIONAL HEALTH ACT 1953
This Determination, among other things, extends the list of institutions for which benefits are payable to recover the cost of supplying homograft items.

The part of the Determination that deals with institutions recovering benefits is contained in Appendix A. The Determination itself, however does not refer to Appendix A or, in fact, mention institutions at all. The Committee has written to the Minister asking whether the instrument validly effects its intention to implement Appendix A.
MIGRATION (1993) REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.235
The Regulations, among other things, create a new class of entry permit.

The new provisions expressly exclude a de facto relationship from the definition of marital relationship for that entry permit. The Committee noted that the principal Regulations generally define marital relationship to include a de facto relationship and has written to the Minister seeking an explanation for this exclusion. Advice has also been sought on whether the exclusion could be considered a breach of personal rights.

LIQUOR LICENSING ACT 1988 (W.A.)(C.K.I.) (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE 1993 TERRITORY OF COCOS (KEELING) ISLANDS ORDINANCE NO.7 OF 1993 LIQUOR LICENSING ACT 1988 (W.A.)(C.I.) (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE 1993 TERRITORY OF CHRISTMAS ISLAND ORDINANCE NO.8 OF 1993
These Ordinances amend the Liquor Licensing Act 1988 (W.A.)(C.I.) and (C.K.I.) in its application to the two Territories.

There are important discretions relating to club, hotel and restaurant liquor licences in new ss.4(1), 37(5), 50(4) and 63(2) of both Ordinances. The Explanatory Statements advise that there is a right of review to the Liquor Licensing Court of the discretion in s.4(1). The Committee has written to the Minister seeking an assurance that similar review exists for the other discretions.
DETERMINATIONS NOS. T65/93 AND T68/93 MADE UNDER S.26 OF THE HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING ACT 1988
These Determinations determine expenditure for approved capital projects for specified institutions and vary funds for operating purposes for institutions throughout Australia.

The Determinations, which reduce some amounts of expenditure, are expressed to operate from the date of making. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking an assurance that both Determinations were gazetted on that day, thus avoiding invalidity under s.48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. That subsection provides that provisions which prejudice any person apart from the Commonwealth are void if expressed to commence before gazettal.
TRAINING GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)
STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.252
The Regulations authorise the Minister to make decisions about recognised alternative training levy schemes and recognition for persons covered by such schemes.

New r.2CC(7) provides appropriately for AAT review of these direct decisions by the Minister. There could, however, be disputes of fact under the provisions of new rr.2CC(5) and (6), even though those provisions are not drafted as discretions. The Committee considers that it may be appropriate to provide for review of decisions made under these two provisions and has written to the Minister accordingly.
AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION ORDER NO.M62/93 MADE UNDER S.16H OF THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION ACT 1977
The Order sets out the principles for the allocation of quotas for meat exports to the United States of America for 1993.

The definition of New Exports Allocation in paragraph 1.1 appears as drafted to subdelegate to the AMLC itself the power to vary the legislated quota without making a fresh instrument under the Act every time it does so. This would appear to be invalid. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking an assurance that any variation of the quota from time to time will be made under s.16H of the parent Act.

Paragraph 3.3 provides a discretion with the AMLC to vary a quota, expressed as `in its absolute discretion and without giving reasons'. The Committee notes that it is unusual to provide for a discretion worded in such a way, particularly as there are no criteria to guide and limit its exercise. In addition, the express provision that reasons for decisions need not be given would appear to breach the rights of those affected. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking an assurance that this wide power is either subject to AAT review or comes within Administrative Review Council guidelines for exclusion from such review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That amendments 1 and 2 of the Schedule of amendments to the Nursing Homes Financial Arrangments Principles, contained in Principles NHP 4/1993, made under subsection 40AA(7) of the National Health Act 1953, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1990-91 budget the Hawke government announced that from January 1993 funding of workers compensation costs in nursing homes would be based on a state average. Previously, nursing homes had been fully cost reimbursed for workers compensation costs. State averages are calculated by adding all the workers compensation costs of nursing homes in a state and dividing this figure by the payroll. This figure is expressed as a percentage and each nursing home in the state receives workers compensation funding equal to that percentage of its payroll.

PARA.TAB: If actual workers compensation costs exceed the funded amount, the nursing home must make up the shortfall. Alternatively, if the funded amount exceeds the actual cost, the nursing home keeps the difference. In response to concerns from the industry about administrative problems entailed in not commencing the change at the start of a financial year, their onset was postponed until 1 July 1993. The change was included in a special Commonwealth of Australia Gazette on 28 June 1993. The amendments to the nursing homes' funding arrangements were tabled in the Senate on 27 June 1993 and are disallowable instruments under section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act.

Any explanation of why the coalition is seeking to disallow the amendments in this instrument must commence by stating that the post-election decision not to send this matter to the Gregory review is yet another of Labor's broken election promises. The government tried to quieten down the nursing homes by saying that something would be done about it after the election. The nursing homes were duped.

In an obvious attempt to take this contentious issue off the agenda during the campaign, Mr Staples advised the private and voluntary sectors in late February. A number of them told me that they had been told through telephone conversations that the changes to the workers compensation funding arrangements would be incorporated into the review of the structured nursing home funding arrangements, or the review that we more commonly know as the Gregory review.

After the 1993 election, as I have said, the new minister, Mr Howe, reneged on his predecessor's promise—workers compensation would not be part of Professor Gregory's review and the changes would start up as originally planned on 1 July 1993. Mr Staples's promise was made in the middle of the election campaign. It was a Labor election promise to the nursing home industry, which was unanimously opposed to this change. It was made for purely political reasons, to keep the industry quiet during the election campaign. Mr Howe's post-election reneging on this undertaking is, as I said, just another Labor broken election promise.

A large number of objections to the changes have been put forward by nursing homes and their industry representatives. Many of these claims relate to the nature of the nursing home working environment. It is a difficult environment, as we all know. Those of us who visit nursing homes know some of the situations in which those dedicated staff work. It is difficult to protect against serious accidents due to catastrophic events.

Sometimes through no fault of their own, residents of nursing homes do not always act in a way that is reasonable and safe. In addition, the main compensatory injury in nursing homes—that is, back injury as a result of heavy lifting—involves high claims. It is very prone to rorting, often recurs and it is very difficult to protect against these sorts of injuries, even with the very best work practices.

It is also argued that the proposed system will not necessarily reward or punish those homes that deserve to be rewarded or punished. A nursing home with a large number of small claims as a result of poor work practices may not incur as large a funding shortfall as a home that is unlucky enough to have a single major claim that has nothing to do with its work practices.

The proposed average is a mean average. It is not a case of 50 per cent of nursing homes gaining and 50 per cent of nursing homes losing from the new system. I meant `mean' as in average—not `mean' in the other sense of the word. Analysis of a frequency distribution, which I have obtained through questions on notice, shows that 60 to 70 per cent of homes will get a bonus, while 30 to 40 per cent of homes will have a shortfall. The size of the shortfall that results from the use of this average is of concern, particularly in states where premiums vary significantly.

In Victoria, some 40 homes have premiums four per cent or more above the designated state average. With a payroll of $2 million, a 50-bed nursing home in this category is looking at a shortfall of $80,000 a year. Aged Care Australia has given examples of two Tasmanian nursing homes with premiums of $170,000 a year each being underfunded by $85,000 a year. Shortfalls of this size mean that other homes will receive quite significant bonuses. Aged Care Australia has given another example of a Tasmanian home with a premium of $13,000 a year that will get $53,000 in funding.

The state averaging system is, by necessity, retrospective. The original averages are based on care aggregated module, or CAM, payroll figures in the NH20 returns for the 1991-92 financial year. The actual average will be calculated from the 1993-94 NH20s, and the difference between it and the amount paid to the nursing home will be recovered or paid via a loading.

The 1992-93 NH20 form and future NH20s will include an additional standard aggregated module, or SAM, payroll component so that the average is based on the total payroll. When fully operational, the system entails using the reconciliation from two years previous to determine an estimate of the current year's average, assessing the current year's reconciliation during the following year to redetermine that average and adjusting the amount paid to the individual nursing home commensurately. Aged Care Australia has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The time lag may well be in the order of fifteen months before a nursing home knows whether it has made a profit or incurred a loss on workers' compensation premiums.

The Private Geriatric Hospitals Association of Victoria—PGHAV—has provided a detailed submission which argues persuasively that the interaction of the averaging system with the new Victorian work cover scheme may have major adverse financial repercussions if a nursing home suffers a serious accident amongst its staff.

PARA.TAB: The work cover scheme is fully funded each financial year and interim premiums are adjusted accordingly. This means that, while the Commonwealth is recovering excess workers compensation funding, the Victorian government will be adjusting its interim premium upwards to take account of the claims experienced during the previous year. This means that, as the premium costs go up, the Commonwealth's funding goes down. The PGHAV claims that this will be very detrimental if a nursing home has a serious accident amongst its staff, especially highly paid staff in a small home, regardless of how well the home runs in all other aspects.

A number of other sources have expressed state specific concerns about the impact of the workers compensation changes. There are wide disparities in the premiums paid by nursing homes in South Australia, which also has the highest state average. This means that shortfalls and bonuses may be very large. The Commonwealth has already adjusted the Tasmanian average upwards as a result of concerns expressed by the industry. An actuary in Western Australia has argued that that state's average is one percentage point too low.

While the Commonwealth has provided an exemption for transit accidents, the Victorian system does not cover such accidents. The Victorian system encourages claiming workers to make an early return to light duties. But the CAM funding system for nursing homes does not recognise light duties.

The minister claims that the industry has been given sufficient lead time since the change was originally announced in 1990 to improve its workers compensation claiming record. However, there is little evidence that the Commonwealth has acted positively to support such improvements. In answer to a question on notice, the government claims that it has funded a number of nursing home occupational health and safety related projects. However, closer scrutiny reveals that only three small projects have been funded, the earliest being approved in October 1992, two years after the original announcement in the 1990 budget.
At ground level, there is virtually no evidence of direct assistance from the Commonwealth reaching individual nursing homes. Objective No. 7 of the nursing homes outcome standards states:

SPEECH.PARA: The nursing home environment and practices will ensure the safety of residents and staff.

It is the task of the standards monitoring teams to monitor and, if necessary, enforce these standards. However, to date, the department has not seen fit to extend the role of the standards monitoring teams by taking up opportunities to have an educational role in occupational health and safety.

PARA.TAB: In virtually all workers compensation systems, employers' premiums are directly related to their previous claims record. When a nursing home changes hands, the new proprietor inherits the old proprietor's good or bad claims record. More often than not, it is a bad claims record, particularly if the previous owner has had financial difficulties. This means that premiums may remain above the average for a considerable time, even if a new proprietor has impeccable workplace health and safety practices.

For example, a nursing home which I visited in Tasmania very recently claims that it is facing a $60,000 annual deficit as a result of this change because its current high premiums reflect the poor practices of the previous proprietor. That just seems very difficult to comprehend. In this example, the new proprietor is also paying negative loadings incurred by the previous proprietor as well as undertaking expensive structural upgrading and replacement work on a property that was approved by the department as being okay for a nursing home. Apparently, it has quite significant structural problems. This change will be an additional significant burden. It will also act as a disincentive to purchasers taking over run-down nursing homes in the future.

It needs to be stressed that only the government appears to be supporting the change. Since I have become shadow minister, this issue has been the subject of an ongoing campaign by the nursing home industry; it is an issue which inevitably comes up when I visit nursing homes. All three of the national industry bodies in the voluntary and private sectors are opposed to the change.

The Victorian Hospitals Association, which represents state public nursing homes in that state, is opposed to the change. The Private Geriatric Hospitals Association in Victoria, the PGHAV, has provided an in-depth analysis of the change, concluding that its interaction with the Victorian system will have an adverse impact on its members. A number of individual nursing homes have expressed their concerns to the coalition either directly or through their industry bodies.

In response to this widespread concern, I wrote to the major industry groups in July asking them to provide alternatives to the government's proposed averaging system. I stipulated that the alternatives must entail an incentive to improve occupational health and safety practices. We are all agreed—the government, the opposition, the Democrats, and the industry—that there needs to be some checks and balances in there to encourage and improve occupational health and safety practices. The three criteria I gave the industry in July were that the alternatives must, firstly, entail an incentive to improve occupational health and safety practices; secondly, be revenue neutral; and, thirdly, be administratively simple.

All three national bodies stated that they were in favour of a system that would reward nursing homes with good occupational health and safety practices and penalise those homes with bad practices. It was not that they wanted to keep the system as it is, paying workers compensation at whatever rate it was. They realised that that was untenable and could not continue.

The alternative put forward by Aged Care Australia best fulfilled the criteria that I had set out. It involved a weighted averaging system in which homes with costs above the average would receive funding at a rate above the average but less than their premium, while homes paying below the average would receive funding at a rate less than the average but more than their premium.

A similar system based on tolerance levels was put forward by the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association, while the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals put forward a more complicated alternative that took account of catastrophic events.

Without doubt, the change put forward by the government introduces a significant incentive into the workers compensation funding system for nursing homes. However, one must ask whether it is an appropriate incentive, whether it will reward and penalise the right people for the right reasons, and whether it will have any unintended adverse consequences for nursing homes.

It is questionable whether a nursing home should get a windfall from the government of up to $40,000 per year simply because it has a low workers compensation premium, regardless of the reason why it has a low premium. It is also concerning that a nursing home may be out of pocket to the extent of $60,000 a year as a result of claims that may be unrelated to its own occupational health and safety practices. It could be a catastrophic event that occurs. The nursing home could have had the best occupational health and safety practices in the industry and still be in a situation where it is likely to lose significant amounts of money. For many of those nursing homes, that amount of money actually threatens their viability.

The government has not introduced the necessary safeguards into its averaging system to protect nursing homes whose viability is threatened by this system or which are financially disadvantaged by it for reasons which are beyond their control. There is no appeal mechanism. There are no exclusions for special circumstances, other than the $500,000 or above transit claim provision. There is little evidence that this highly regulated industry, which is almost wholly reliant on Commonwealth funding for its survival, has received sufficient support from the government since the 1990 announcement to improve its occupational health and safety practices.

Worst of all, the post-election decision by the minister to commence this provision from 1 July without referring it to Professor Gregory's review as promised during the election campaign is a blatant example of how this government is quite willing to say one thing before the election—it said bald faced that there would be no new taxes and all pensioners would be taken out of the tax system—and then after the election change its mind. Exactly the same thing has happened in the nursing home industry.

Those opposite ought to squirm because this is the sort of thing that goes on all the time. People are gullible and they believe the government. They will not believe it next time. The government said to the nursing home industry that this matter would be sent off to the Gregory review. We believe that promise ought to be kept.

In my notice of motion today, I gave the government the opportunity to abide by its election promise to the industry and refer this matter to the Gregory review. As the government has not seen fit to take up this offer, I have no choice but to move to disallow those parts of this instrument that refer to changes to the funding of nursing home workers' compensation funding.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting Senator Patterson's disallowance motion. Senator Patterson has covered virtually all the major concerns and in particular she has dealt with some of the financial difficulties that will be faced by the nursing home industry if this goes ahead. She has also covered much of the historical context of this difficulty.

PARA.TAB: My main concern is that I really cannot see that these regulations will necessarily do anything to improve occupational health and safety in nursing homes, which is what we are supposed to be looking at. Although I fully appreciate that full cost reimbursement provides no incentive whatsoever for nursing homes to improve their work practices and their workers' compensation claiming records, I am not convinced that the measures in these regulations will actually act as an incentive. I think the government is proposing to use a very blunt instrument which ultimately may not prove to be anything like the right instrument for the job—in other words, a sledgehammer to crack a nut.

The Democrats are not saying that the government should abandon its attempts to get some improvement in this area. We are not saying that the current situation is satisfactory and that full cost reimbursement is a good system. I accept that it is not a sound system and I certainly understand why the government feels it has to do something to change it. But—and this is a criticism I have had of the minister responsible for this area for some time—this is yet another example of using a blanket approach to correct a problem. Basically people seem to be too lazy to actually get out there in the field, look at what is happening, look at things more closely and work out constructively what needs to be done. Although I do not agree with everything that the aged care industry is necessarily saying about these regulations, I really do think that they have raised sufficient cause for concern to say that the government has to examine again its approach.

I share Senator Patterson's view that the most appropriate course of action is for the matter to be examined by Professor Gregory's current review of the structure of nursing home funding arrangements. I do not want to get into an argument about whether or not the government did tell anybody or which minister told somebody that Professor Gregory would actually look at this matter, because I do not believe that is relevant. But I make the point very clearly that it seems completely ridiculous to have a major review of nursing home funding going on and not have it look at the funding of nursing home workers' compensation premiums as part of its work, specially when there is clearly so much dissatisfaction with what the government is proposing to do.

The obvious course of action is for the government to send the matter off to the Gregory review. It is due to report in April. I am happy to say to the government that if Professor Gregory comes back and says, `The government's got it right all along and this blanket approach is the way to go', the Democrats will be only too happy to look at it again. But at this point we believe waiting until April is not too much to ask when there is so much at stake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not reverse the implementation of this decision, as it addresses a clear flaw in the previous funding arrangements. Until these changes, nursing homes were fully cost reimbursed for workers' compensation costs, regardless of the claiming and safety record of the home. This removed the incentives that the workers' compensation insurance authorities create by increasing premiums for employers who neglect their occupational health and safety obligations. The result of the old system is that nursing homes have a very poor safety record, evidenced by the fact that the base workers' compensation premium for nursing homes in Victoria is almost twice that for private hospitals, their nearest equivalent. It is interesting to note that both Senator Patterson and Senator Lees agree that there is considerable room for improvement.
—So does the industry.

—So does the industry. I must say that the arguments used by my colleagues, particularly Senator Patterson, were very unpersuasive. Senator Patterson said that there are people, for example, who suffer back injury in nursing homes and that this is an area that is being rorted in the nursing home industry. `Rorted' was her word; I wrote it down. She said that back injury was very hard to test. I think her words were that a good system could not get around these rorts any more than a bad system. With respect, it most certainly can. That is what she was saying. I think it is important that we stay on the point and not be distracted.

PARA.TAB: We cannot improve compensation practices by ignoring them or by leaving the current system in place. There can be no improvement by not looking at the question of micro-economic reform and building in incentives for nursing homes to improve. It is part of good management. I am sure that Senator Patterson, who is snorting over there, has some reason for doing it. To ask me to take account of the fact that back injury is easily rortable and is currently being rorted and that nothing would change that I think is a very unpersuasive argument.

I remind Senator Patterson again that at the moment nursing homes have a very poor safety record and the basic workers' compensation premium for nursing homes in Victoria is almost twice that of private hospitals, their nearest equivalent. Clearly, while some people in nursing homes have an opportunity to move around, we cannot exactly equate a nursing home with a private hospital. They are not without some considerable relevance, particularly if it involves back injury from lifting. It is interesting that private hospitals have a different record altogether. I do not think that point can be made strongly enough.

To overcome this situation and to improve conditions for staff and residents of nursing homes, the government decided in 1990 that, from 1993, workers' compensation costs would be funded in nursing homes on the basis of state average costs. Under the new funding arrangements, homes which have lower than average premiums are able to keep the difference between their funding and their actual costs. This provides a positive incentive for all nursing homes to improve their safety practices. Over 60 per cent of homes have lower than average costs and are gaining from the change.

Some representatives of nursing homes claim that workers' compensation premiums are not dependent on management decisions or safety practices. However, many nursing homes are taking steps to improve safety practices in order to reduce premiums and to improve safety for their staff and residents. A church home in New South Wales achieved a 37 per cent reduction in premiums over three years as a result of its efforts.

The government does not see any reason to disadvantage a majority of homes with good safety records by reverting to the previous system. This measure provides an incentive for good practice and efficiency. It is entirely consistent with micro-economic reform initiatives aimed at improving efficiency and bringing down overall labour costs—in this case by making the working lives of nursing home staff safer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—I am quite surprised that Senator Patterson would laugh, indeed sneer, at the proposal that good efficiency—
—I am not sneering at the proposal; I am laughing at you, Senator Crowley.

—I am glad that Senator Patterson finds a distinction, but it is the argument we are talking about here. It is entirely consistent to introduce efficiencies of this sort. When efficiencies are associated with good management, we will see an improvement in the safety of the nursing home staff and patients. That is what we want in the end. It is this which the opposition seeks to overturn.
—Oh, rubbish.

—Well, it does. If passed, this motion will take the industry back to a situation where there is no reward for good management practice and no consequence for employers who neglect workplace safety, because the taxpayer will pick up the bill.

PARA.TAB: A number of misunderstandings have clouded discussion of this change at various times. The costs funded will be the average cost in the nursing home industry, so the poorer than average starting point in the nursing home sector will not disadvantage the industry. The costs funded in each nursing home will also be calculated on costs in that state so that homes in states with higher premiums will not be disadvantaged. The average used will be a proportion of the payroll in each home so that the actual amount will vary with the size of the payroll of the home. Larger homes will not be disadvantaged.

The homes have had three years warning in recognition that premiums are calculated on an employer's claiming record ranging from one to three years previously. This should have provided sufficient time for homes to take steps to improve their claiming record. Early in the three-year lead time, a number of steps were taken to inform nursing homes of this change.

Costs of occupational health and safety training have been made an acceptable expense under nursing and personal care funding. I think that certainly counters the implication, at least, of some of Senator Patterson's comments. A number of projects to develop and implement such training have been funded under the aged care program. I appreciate that there is apprehension in some parts of the nursing home industry that there will still be accidents in nursing homes which will cause an unexpected jump in premiums above the average for their state. When instances have been examined by the department, however, these have not proven to be as drastic as feared by the nursing home.

In the state with the highest losses on the part of homes with poorer than average records the average loss is estimated to be around $28,000. By contrast, in the state with the lowest average loss for homes with poor records the average loss is under $5,000. This is offset, of course, by gains which would be made with homes with good records.

A couple of homes have suggested that they will sustain a large loss and will be unable to continue to operate under the new system. For this to happen the home would have to be a long way above the average cost as a result of a very large history of claims. There is no way of protecting employers from the consequences of such a history of poor management practice that does not involve penalising homes with good safety records.

The new funding arrangements correct a longstanding anomaly and provide an incentive structure which will improve safety for both the employees and the residents of nursing homes. So I again say that the government will not reverse its decision.
I note that both Senator Lees and Senator Patterson referred to Professor Gregory. Professor Gregory dealt with this issue in his published report which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Workers' Compensation costs were originally categorised in the same manner but in 1990 the Government decided that proprietors must be encouraged to try to provide a safe working environment for staff. Funding was therefore amended to pay nursing homes the average workers' compensation cost percentage of payroll for a State. This provides a significant incentive for proprietors because, if they can reduce their percentage of premium to payroll to less than the State average percentage for nursing homes, then they can retain the margin between their premium and the amount funded as profit. If they exceed the State average, they will be responsible for meeting the additional cost from what would otherwise have been their return on investment from within SAM.

In other words, we have what Professor Gregory might want to say. I understand that both Senator Lees and Senator Patterson were suggesting that this issue could have gone to Professor Gregory for review; well, we have Professor Gregory's view on this matter already on record. As I said, the government will not reverse the implementation of this decision so I am not persuaded by the arguments put here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to put on the record that I was not suggesting we go back to the old system. That is absolutely ridiculous. If the regulation is disallowed, the government can go back to the drawing board and actually consult with the industry. I will say this again very slowly so that the minister can understand what I said. Because there was widespread concern in the industry, I wrote to the industry in July to put up some alternatives. I said that the alternatives must entail—listen carefully—an incentive to improve occupational health and safety practices, be revenue neutral and be administratively simple. I am not saying, nor is the industry saying, that we should go back.

PARA.TAB: All three bodies—I will say it again slowly so that the minister understands—stated that they were in favour of a system that would reward nursing homes with good occupational health and safety practices and penalise those homes with bad practices. Never did I say that we should go back to the old system. We are saying that we need a system that addresses the concerns that the whole industry has. If the government and the minister bothered to consult with the industry—and this would happen on many occasions—they would find that they could reach some compromises. The industry has come up with some suggestions.

I did not suggest, nor did the Democrats, that we go back to the old system. I have clearly restated what I suggested. The minister said we were suggesting that we go back to the old system. I just want it clearly on the public record that that is not right. I do not think that anything the minister said convinced me that we should change our minds.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that notice of motion No. 396, standing in my name, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 3, standing in the name of Senator Kernot, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion no. 396 standing in the name of Senator Coulter, relating to world population growth.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is one of the most important matters ever to come before this parliament, that is, whether the idiosyncratic views of one senator alone should dictate the foreign policy of Australians specifically with respect to that part of our foreign aid program which is given to family planning and population limitation. If a deal was done between Senator Harradine and the government, it was particularly shabby, but I must say that I accept Senator Harradine's explanation that this was not a deal. In any case, there is the far more important issue, the substantive issue regarding the partial suspension of our aid for family planning and limitation of the frightening rate of population growth globally, and specifically in Third World countries.

PARA.TAB: I hope that all senators who are here will support this motion for the suspension of standing orders and agree that there should be an immediate conscience vote on the substantive motion so that senators will have the opportunity to vote on this issue. In that way there would be a minimum loss of time.

The population issue is one half of the total environmental debate. The other half is the per capita impact. One can put together every aspect of environmental damage—whether it is local, continental or global, concerning the impact of greenhouse gases or the impact we are having on ozone depletion—and population is one half of that equation. To fail to recognise that is to fail to recognise that population is the most important issue which now faces humankind. We cannot afford to ignore the question of population, and specifically the rapid rate of population growth.

World population is now increasing faster than at any time in human history. Every 11 years another one billion people are added to the world population. They demand more food, more shelter and more energy for their existence—indeed, a share of the ability to pollute and damage the environment, the atmosphere and the waters of the environment and to impact on the limited resources of planet earth. Limiting the rate of population growth reduces the rate at which the pressure of people on the planet increases; it provides a breathing space for attention to the per capita impacts of people on the environment.

Two of the most important principles which underlie sustainable development are the precautionary principle and the principle of intergenerational equity. If we are in doubt about the ability of the earth to sustain seven billion, eight billion, 10 billion, 11 billion or 20 billion people, the precautionary principle says that we should slow down the rate of population growth until we are sure. We should not simply go on hell-bent on increasing the population. Intergenerational equity means that we would give to future generations the same access to resources that we have today.

The other main issue is the right of women to determine their own fertility practices. There are 125 million people in the world today who wish to use the services of family planning, who wish to space their families, who wish to limit the size of their families, and who are being denied that right by Senator Harradine and people like him who will not allow those people to make a choice. It is their right to make a choice determined by their moral codes and not to be dictated to by somebody in Australia. There is a clear link between mortality in children and mothers and family size. This is another issue of great importance. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter probably has not given a great deal of consideration to the matters before the chamber at the moment, and the significant amount of government business and legislation that we have to deal with. Clearly, at this stage, although there is no doubting the significance to all senators of the issues raised in Senator Coulter's notice of motion, it would be inappropriate, given that we have a number of opportunities in this chamber for these issues to be raised, for us to have a very extensive debate at this time on this particular motion. I do not know how much thought Senator Coulter has given to the difficulties that we have, but there are opportunities for honourable senators, apart from taking up time like this, to debate issues of substance.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the substantive points that Senator Coulter has made, it has come to light recently that the original reports which related to the suspension of population activities were largely misleading. In fact, expenditure on population activities has not been halted, nor, for that matter, I think it is fair to say, has it been slowed down.

The substantial increase in population related activities to a total of $30 million in 1993-94 and $130 million over the four years to 1996-97 was announced in the budget. The 1993-94 commitment of $30 million is a three-fold increase over the $10 million that was spent last year and nearly five times that which was spent in 1991-92. There is no doubt that the lack of family planning services in developing countries is an important, crucial and pressing human rights, development and environment issue; it is certainly also one that the Australian government is determined to address.

At the time of the announcement of the review that has been referred to, the $30 million set aside for expenditure in 1993-94 had been almost totally committed—all but $3.25 million—to specific projects and programs to assist population and family planning programs in developing countries. That expenditure of $26.75 million is now going ahead. Similarly, of the $130 million programmed to be spent over the next four years, $96 million has already been committed and will be unaffected by the suspension of the remaining part of the program. I think that represents a genuine honouring of commitments that were made.

Nevertheless, it is the case that the expenditure of $3.25 million this financial year and a further $30.75 million over the following three financial years has been put on hold pending a fully independent review conducted by experts and development economists. I believe that that is a reasonably rational way for us to go. It will mean that these matters will be looked at on a sound intellectual basis and the inquiry will be completed by March,

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise at short notice to support Senator Harradine on this matter. Senator Coulter accused Senator Harradine of being the only senator in this place to hold the views on birth control that he does; I can assure Senator Coulter that Senator Harradine is not the only senator in this place to hold those views. I support Senator Harradine in what he has done on this matter. I do not hold similar religious views to those of Senator Harradine, my religion not being the same as his, so I do not support him for that reason and cannot be accused of that sort of push. But I am concerned that the government was going to increase funding rapidly—and this morning Senator Faulkner outlined the amounts over the next few years—at the expense of what I would call practical aid to developing countries which would be of far more benefit to those particular countries.

PARA.TAB: I do not know why Senator Coulter has to bring this matter before this parliament with such haste with only a few weeks left before Christmas in which to discuss a big agenda of very demanding matters. I know this question is a very serious one. It one that I, and I know a lot of my colleagues, would like a lot more time to prepare for, for there to be a proper and full debate. I object to this being brought forward this morning in this way, as I am sure most of my colleagues would too.

I have heard these sorts of comments about the population increasing before. I remember in my farming days being told that, if I hung around farming long enough, the year 1984 would bring the biggest world shortage of food that had ever been seen, and that every farmer would be very prosperous because we would be working flat out producing food for the starving millions of the world. It is now 1993 and I am in this place, not on the farm, and that boom in the production of food never arrived.

I also remember very well the dire warnings. We can all remember the starving millions in India—and I am not saying that there are not still starving millions of people in India—but Australia itself was providing very practical aid to India and helping India to produce enough food to feed its millions of people. In fact, we find now that India is a net exporter of wheat, and it is not that long ago that we were providing massive aid.

Practical aid to all these disadvantaged and so-called overpopulated countries is the way to go. In my opinion, to try at short notice to take freedom of choice from parents in these countries is not the way to go. People should still have the God-given right to have children that they can look after; not to spend money on the sorts of things that have been happening, which Senator Harradine has brought out in estimates over the years, such as the abuse of females with all these untried and unknown drugs. Even now, we find questions being raised about ultrasound equipment which has been used in our own country. Women themselves are starting to realise that a lot of these so-called birth control measures that we are funding are very deleterious to their health.

Senator Coulter's efforts to pull this stunt this morning—bringing on a notice of motion and then trying to get it debated, without giving anybody any prior advice—is not the way to go. DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION (RESOLUTION OF COMPLAINTS) BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FUNDING) LEVY BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION (ROLLED-OVER BENEFITS) LEVY BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY (SUPERVISION) CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY (SUPERVISION) BILL 1993OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS AMENDMENT BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee has before it the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993. This is an important part of the higher prudential standards to be applied to superannuation in this country. It is important because many of the traditional ways of handling disputes such as through the court system are expensive and lengthy. Most members do not have either the resources or the confidence in their ability to tackle trustees in circumstances where they believe they have been unfairly treated.

PARA.TAB: Currently, there is before the committee, on behalf of the Liberal-National coalition, an amendment in respect of the complaints tribunal. The tribunal cannot deal with a complaint about a trustee's decision if it is about a benefit that was paid before the commencement of the act and—it is this `and' that is so important and which I think a lot of people have lost sight of—if the benefit was paid in whole or in part to a person other than the complainant.

The amendment is in two parts and is very restrictive, far more restrictive than the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. For example, it does not stop the lodgment of all complaints before the commencement date of 1 July 1994, only those where it was paid in whole or in part to a person other than the complainant. Therefore, I would submit that well over 90 per cent—perhaps 95 per cent—of the expected cases which are likely to come before the tribunal would be affected by the decision.

The government's intention to reject this amendment would cause suffering in an area where, most probably, those people have greatest need for the cash resources and the cash payment that would flow from the trustee's decision. The issue is the consequence that will flow if the government and any other parties reject this amendment. The consequences of rejection of our amendment would be that the trustees would automatically delay payment in necessitous circumstances where there is the probability or the possibility of dispute because it would give rise to a double jeopardy position. The delay could well be for between six and nine months because we know that there will be a string of cases before the tribunal after 1 July because cases before 1 July 1994 in respect of problems can be heard by the tribunal after 1 July. Given the resources of the tribunal, one could well find that people would be denied an otherwise legitimate payment for up to 12 months in most necessitous circumstances. I think this is quite unfair.

For example, a trustee could not run the risk in circumstances where money was paid out in good faith to a named beneficiary such as a widow. The money is paid out to the widow and subsequently, six or eight months down the track, along comes the de facto and says, `Well, this was unfair. I have been living with this chap for 24 years. I am the true beneficiary'. The tribunal would then make up its mind and say, `In the interests of natural justice—the other lady has moved off, is unknown, is perhaps living in another state—we will declare that the moneys should be paid to the de facto lady because she had been living with the deceased for a good number of years'.

In such circumstances, what hope would the trustees have of getting that money back, paid in good faith to the widow? It would create a double jeopardy position for the trustees. Particularly in small funds, it could severely embarrass the cash position of the fund and place in jeopardy the interests of the remaining members of the fund. I am sure that that is not what would be required. Therefore, I ask the government to reconsider its position. It is a small amendment. It will not affect a lot of people. The point is the consequences that will flow from the refusal of the trustees to pay out if there is any doubt at all about their decision being upset subsequently by the tribunal. They are not given the time delay because of cases being stacked up.

Because we are looking into the future, I would ask the government and any other honourable senator who has any doubt about supporting my amendment to reconsider their position. It is in line with recommendation No. 16.1 of the Senate select committee, which had cross-party support from the Democrats and the Labor Party, but I remind honourable senators that this is more restrictive than that particular recommendation, and there is all the more reason for the Senate to support it.

I also remind the Senate that complainants still have the right of access to the court system, as they do now, where they have this sort of difficulty. Obviously the tribunal process, which we recommend, is a very inexpensive method and it is a good invention. But I think we have to be very careful that we do not disadvantage people in circumstances where they could be denied a legitimate payment, simply because trustees will be warned, wherever there is a doubt, not to pay because such payment could be overridden subsequently by the tribunal. That is the greater problem. Then there is the associated problem that these people, who will be in necessitous circumstances, will be denied access to this money. I ask the government, through Senator Sherry, a very capable former chairman of that committee, to reconsider its position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for the compliment. I will compliment him by saying that he is a very capable current chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. Unfortunately, despite our alleged capabilities, we do not seem to be able to see eye to eye on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The central thrust of Senator Watson's argument is that some people—I accept this—may experience a time delay of nine to 12 months in receiving their payment. But the cure which he is proposing is wrong in principle. The opposition is saying that, in order to minimise that problem, we should deny people altogether the right to appear before the tribunal.

There is a clash of two principles here. The opposition happens to believe that the consequence of the outcome that it has outlined is worse than the principle that the government strongly supports, which is that people should have the right to appear before the tribunal and to argue their case. In some cases, there may be some delay of payment, but at least they will have the right to argue before the tribunal.

Senator Watson said that the issue involves only a few people. It is not a few people. Death disputes occur every day. Hundreds of people would have their right to appear before the tribunal cut off. We just cannot agree to that in principle.

Senator Watson then said that there is an alternative for these people in that they can go to the courts. But how many people have been doing that, and is it a practical option? For example, very few people have gone to the courts with cases dealing with death benefits. In fact, the figures I have seen suggest that it is fewer than 100. People simply cannot succeed there; it is too expensive and it takes too long. So the alternative that Senator Watson is suggesting is also inappropriate.

Two principles are at stake. I accept that Senator Watson is very concerned that there would be a delay in payment—not the abrogation of a payment. I accept that that is probable for some people. But our principal concern, which we argue outweighs Senator Watson's principle, is that we will be cutting off altogether the access of hundreds of people to the tribunal. We argue that, on balance, and having regard to our principle and the numbers of people that would be affected, our argument is stronger. Therefore, we see the amendment that Senator Watson is suggesting as the wrong solution to the problem.

Frankly, I think this problem is probably insoluble because of the phase-in time needed for the operation of the tribunal. There will always be people affected by a cut-off date. But Senator Watson's proposed solution is, in its outcomes, much worse. Frankly, what would the Senate committee say to people who have complained to it over the last year or two about being disadvantaged and who come back to it and ask, `Why did you cut off our right to appear before the tribunal'? Whilst the principle that Senator Watson has enunciated has validity, it is outweighed by the approach and the principle that we are adopting in opposing this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) a question about the likely volume of work that the tribunal will be required to bear within, for example, the first six months of its operation. This question impinges directly upon Senator Watson's point about the problem of people in necessitous circumstances.

PARA.TAB: If there are going to be considerable delays in the settlement of complaints because of the volume of work to be shouldered by the tribunal, there really is a problem. It may be an insoluble problem, but that will not put bread on the table of likely beneficiaries who rely on that income for their standard of living.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of those incredibly difficult situations where there are two competing principles which both have merit. I am really at a loss to know what is the best way to go. We are considering the withdrawal of this amendment. Perhaps it is possible for us to talk to the ISC again about giving it the power to protect trustee decisions in clear-cut cases. Unfortunately, Senator Watson is occupied at the moment and cannot hear what I am saying about his amendment. Perhaps I will finish my remarks when he returns.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to Senator Harradine's question. The volume of complaints involving death benefits and superannuation is small compared to the total volume of complaints. Evidence given before the committee certainly suggests that it is small. I cannot give Senator Harradine figures on it, but we do know that it tends to be a fairly small area, albeit an important one because people are waiting for money from the resolution of their death benefit case. At present, trustees have an absolute power to determine these issues. There is the common law, but, as I mentioned, it is frankly inaccessible for the member of a fund.

PARA.TAB: From past experience, we believe that the proportion of this type of complaint compared to the total volume of complaints to the tribunal is quite small. Therefore, we believe that the likely time of resolution for a death benefit dispute will be six to nine months. That is a delay, but it is not an unreasonable period in which to consider the outcome and adjudicate on a death benefit dispute. So there would be some delay, but it is not significant in terms of time and the volume of the tribunal's work. The tribunal could well decide to give those issues priority because of the urgent nature of a death benefit case and the need to pay the beneficiary. Those problems can be overcome.

We have to consider that set of problems in the context of what Senator Watson is proposing, which is to cut off altogether the right of some people to have access to the tribunal. I would argue that that is a worse outcome for hundreds of people—we do not know how many—in this category. It is a very difficult principle. I understand Senator Kernot's dilemma, but the government has thought about this a great deal—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not have an answer until 10 minutes ago.

—That was a very unkind comment. We cannot support the amendment. I came in before breakfast this morning and looked long and hard at this issue and at the report. I also read through our previous reports. This is an important issue. The more I have thought about it, the more I think, on balance, that the amendment suggested by Senator Watson is evidence of the wrong approach.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is one thing to deny access, but what is the government going to say to all those people who are in incredible hardship and who are going to have to wait for maybe 12 months? What is it going to say to trustees who will not want to—nor should they—pay out twice? I understand the principle of protecting access, but what do we say to the others?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are going to have to refer a copy of the Hansard of this debate to them to highlight the dilemma. What do we say to hundreds of people when they come to us and say, `Why did you cut our access off all together?' We say to them, `You have got a common law remedy'. But, in practice, they will not take that remedy. They have not done so in the past. One of the reasons for introducing a tribunal is the less time it will take to resolve disputes vis-a-vis common law and the normal courts of law. I do not think anyone is seriously going to argue that a common law approach will be quicker or less costly. It will be much more costly and it will take more time.

—It is possible, sure. I think we have to ask ourselves honestly: how many people, given past experience, are going to access common law? The interesting thing about disputes of this nature involving death benefits—certainly from sitting as a trustee on funds making decisions like this—is that some of the payments are not substantial. Some payments might be less than $10,000; in many cases they involve quite small sums of money. Frankly, is it worth people going through the courts of law arguing common law—and in many cases, I suspect, trying to break new ground—when the legal fee that they will have to pay to recover what could be a significant sum of money to them will take a significant bite out of the moneys that they may receive from the trustees on a death benefit?

—What is the legal position of trustees being able to recover money which they paid out in good faith to what they believed was a genuine beneficiary in a case where the decision is subsequently overturned by the tribunal? To collect this money could create undue hardship to the beneficiary who has probably spent the money—paid off a house or helped educate children. What is the legal position in the case of, say, a genuine person who received money in good faith—it was bona fide paid out—but the situation was subsequently upset by the tribunal?

PARA.TAB: What does the government think the existing members of the fund are going to say about the double jeopardy position—essentially having to make a payout twice in respect of a beneficiary who was a former member of the fund? It creates a double jeopardy position. It could cause a financial problem for small funds.

I acknowledge the important point raised by the parliamentary secretary. But at the end of the day the government has to weigh up the consequences of its decision. I think it is going to have a lot of very unhappy people. We are not taking away rights that they do not already have. True, the government is creating new rights for them, but we are saying that there are some circumstances in which we believe that the harm caused to individuals would be far greater than any benefits that the government proposes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is quite a simple answer to that. I know that Senator Kernot raised this matter earlier. The simple answer is this: the tribunal will not allow double payment. If the trustees have already made a part or whole payment to a person, and that person then, in some way, attempts to claim a double payment—
—No, a different person.

—Let us say a different person. I have no doubt that the representatives of the trustee would argue before the tribunal that a double payment should not occur. I am sure that any tribunal addressing this, with natural justice in mind, would take that into account in its deliberations. It would be highly unlikely that a tribunal would, in effect, award a double payment. If the trustees argue that way before the tribunal, I am sure the tribunal would take that into account.

—How can Senator Sherry, with any degree of confidence, try to prejudge in every circumstance how the tribunal is going to take the argument and disallow any double jeopardy payment? After all, my amendment seeks to prevent double jeopardy and protect payments that are made in good faith on presentation of proper documentation. I cannot imagine that there will be hundreds of these situations, but there will be some. The consequences in a lot of other situations will be that, if there is a doubt, trustees will delay and deny payments because of the waiting time between now and, not only 1 July, but whenever they have time to consider a whole long list of complainants after 1 July.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Sherry can give that assurance with any authority, referring to the act, I will withdraw my amendment. But the whole purpose of my amendment is to make sure that these people are not disadvantaged and that trustees are not placed in this invidious position. We do not want the trustees to be the nasty men denying payment; we want to facilitate the role of trustees and to give them appropriate status. We do not want a situation where they can be sued by other members for not taking due diligence and care.

As a former trustee, Senator Sherry would not like to be put in that position by his existing members for not taking that degree of care and making a payment perhaps earlier than he should have. There would be a lot of his colleagues in a similar position who are good members, good trustees of superannuation funds, who themselves could be personally liable if the tribunal, effectively, made a double payment which, under the terms of the legislation as it now stands, they could be obliged to pay.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just do not agree with Senator Watson on that matter. The delay in payment occurs at the present time anyway. If the trustees have a dispute before them, they will delay payment for as long as it takes for them to resolve it, so delays can already occur.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the way in which the tribunal addresses this issue and refer to the argument that I advanced earlier. Clause 36 of the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill under `meeting procedure' states that the tribunal is required to take into account not just the interests of the person who is making a claim before the tribunal, but also the interests of all the members of the fund. I would argue that that gives the tribunal sufficient power not to award double payments in these circumstances, because it is required to take into account the interests of members of the fund. In doing so, it can avoid the situation advanced by Senator Watson.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the original example that I provided to the Senate. A named widow is a beneficiary on the documents. It subsequently turns out that the deceased was living in a de facto relationship for, say, 20 years. In terms of natural justice, I think that one would find that the tribunal, on the balance of probability, would pay something to that lady, particularly when the whereabouts of the widow was not known or evident until the tribunal hearings. In those sorts of circumstances there are going to be problems. I do not want to create difficulties where genuine people have been paid out and double jeopardy could result so far as funds are concerned—particularly small funds—because it could prejudice the interests of existing members. At the same time, I want to protect the trustees so that they are not liable in the event of a double jeopardy situation arising.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I put to Senator Watson that the debate still has not satisfactorily resolved the competing principles at all. Would Senator Watson consider having the Senate committee take the issue back again? I do not think the committee teased this matter out to that extent.

—If Senator Kernot looks at recommendation 16(1) of the report, she will find that we considered this issue and that there is quite a lot of written material on it. At page 81 or thereabouts of the report we debated that issue. I indicate that the report was far more wide ranging than the particular circumstances that I have looked at. Therefore, I believe that in these circumstances we should support the amendment put forward.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The suggestion put forward by Senator Kernot is a good one. I can give an undertaking on behalf of the government that if the committee examines this issue again and comes back to the government, I cannot say we will accept what it recommends, but we will certainly ensure that the matter is dealt with prior to 1 July next year which is before the tribunal commences operation. That will give the committee time to deal with the competing principles.
—But we would like some more input from you.
—I am happy to give that assurance.

—Given the concerns expressed around the chamber, perhaps the amendment that has been raised by me on behalf of the opposition should be referred back to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation for further consideration in conjunction with representatives from the government. Would that be an acceptable course to follow?
