I draw the attention of the committee to the revised copy which has been circulated. This amendment requires the tribunal to advise claimants of their rights to access specialist superannuation legal centres. It establishes a requirement for the minister to establish such centres by regulation or to provide reasons to each house as to why they are not to be set up.

PARA.TAB: I have basically summarised the effect of the clause. It is important that we have independent legal services for superannuation consumers. We know it is the burgeoning industry in the financial sector. It is important that the minister is required to proclaim regulations or to tell us why he or she would not.

What I have added to the amendment since yesterday's version is a sunset clause of three years. Senator Watson was keen to consider this inclusion and it does accommodate the Senate committee's recommendation which will allow government and industry to work together to discuss and finalise funding arrangements, but in the meantime it gets the principle established and it gets the centres working. Overall the clause seeks to encapsulate the recommendations from the Senate select committee but without the Senate imposing on the House an appropriation requirement.

The very complexity of the SIS bills that we have been debating demonstrates that consumers will need assistance with their complaints. While we should acknowledge that the government intends to resource the tribunal and to have a reasonably substantial secretariat, we should not lose sight of the fact that independent legal advice is a very important principle.

If we were to compare the access of consumers in other areas, we would find that in the last six months of 1992 the two main consumer legal centres in Sydney and Melbourne finalised four major litigation cases, took on 205 smaller cases, made 130 court appearances, gave 2000 telephone advices, negotiated credit policy changes during four licence renewals, distributed 967 how to manuals and produced dozens of media articles and stories. Cases currently being finalised by the centres will deliver consumers more than $5 million in damages.

Even with the best will in the world, I do not believe the secretariat can match that sort of outcome. That is why I think it is important to resource the tribunal, in the first instance, independently and to move towards the Senate committee's recommendation of a government and industry cooperative model.

I think that the centres will fill the void that exists at the moment of representing consumer interests in the superannuation industry. The funds are well represented by ASFA and the government is well represented by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. It is not true that consumers are adequately and proportionately well funded as well. I do not think it is fair to leave it to fall on individuals or overworked trade unions through the industry funds. I think it is important that the advice be independent and that it be consumer orientated. Honourable senators would not be surprised to know that the proposal is strongly supported by AFCO and the Australian Consumers Association.

The important point to make is that the amendment does not compel the government to set up the centres, but it will show that the Senate strongly supports the Senate select committee's recommendation if this amendment is passed. If the government refuses to issue the regulations then, under this amendment, reasons must be provided to both houses of parliament.

The consumer movement estimates that the cost of setting up two specialist legal centres is about $400,000. The cost of linking these centres through liaison officers in the four other states, in already established legal services, would add another $260,000, making a total of $660,000. I think that is a reasonably small investment in the short term, because the sunset clause is in there, to ensure that the rights the parliament is setting up with the SIS bills today are truly enforced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that the amendment moved by Senator Kernot on behalf of the Australian Democrats is far different from what was originally proposed. In its current form, it is certainly much more acceptable. It is certainly very much in line with the thrust of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation's recommendations in providing a greater focus for consumers in the superannuation area, and that is what we applaud.

PARA.TAB: I presume Senator Kernot is talking about amendment 3, clause 16. We do not intend to support amendments 1 or 2. Amendment 3 will have the support of the Liberal-National party coalition because the requirements that Senator Kernot is seeking are not dissimilar to those in clauses 24 and 25 of the complaints bill as it stands. Clause 24 deals with the lodging of the requisite material documents with the tribunal while clause 25 deals with the power to obtain information and documentation. We interpret Senator Kernot's amendment 3 as requiring the provision of similar documentation, on request, by the particular legal services.

We can foresee certain situations where certain trustees may say that there is no legislative authority for this information to be passed to such a tribunal, even though the request has been documented by the potential complainant. Therefore, we believe it is necessary to have such access as a service assisting the complainant to prepare the case before the tribunal. It is important that the lawyers at these legal centres do not appear as a witness or as an advocate before the tribunal. They assist the complainant to prepare the case. We are attempting to provide a low cost service to the consumers. I believe that through this amendment Senator Kernot, on behalf of the Democrats, has provided the means of facilitating that flow of information. It is nothing more and nothing less.

I turn to the issue of funding. If paragraph (c) is not supported, we could have a farcical situation because there has to be some inducement for the government to take the amendment seriously. This bill is not appropriating money for setting up the legal service centres. I believe that these centres can be a very cost-effective way of assisting people. At the end of the day they may be less expensive than adding additional resources to the secretariat of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Therefore, all the government has to do is examine the issue. If it will not proceed to fund in the next budget, it should come back to the parliament and explain why.

I do not see anything wrong with the situation in a democratic sense. We have a recommendation from a parliamentary committee. It will look at the question of funding and it will come back and explain its reasons, particularly in circumstances where it will not accede to that request. What is the problem? The Senate is not appropriating money; we are just asking the government, if it has problems with the funding of it, to come back and explain the problem to the parliament in an open way and say why it feels there is a difficulty in complying, or complying adequately.

We are a responsible Senate; we will not throw money away. We have been told that these centres will initially cost over half a million dollars. In line with the Senate committee's recommendations relating to funding through appropriation, we said that it should be capped for three years and other alternative funding could then be looked at. Following negotiations with Senator Kernot, she was prepared to put a three-year ceiling on that. We thank her for that. Without that, we would not be able to provide our support because it would have been open-ended. I think there are adequate safeguards on all sides. Therefore, the amendment will have the support of the National-Liberal party coalition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —With that indication, the argument might be futile in terms of its outcome, but I will put it nevertheless. In listening to the argument about the creation of independent legal centres, it strikes me as something of an irony that both the opposition and the Democrats are proposing to channel complaints through lawyers when we are seeking a low cost outcome. The thrust of the tribunal approach is to avoid a legalistic approach and to consider issues in a manner somewhat like an industrial tribunal would. In many jurisdictions lawyers are forbidden and therefore they are generally not used and we have the development of a range of advocates and advice deliverers who generally provide their services—from all the evidence—at a lower cost than lawyers.

PARA.TAB: It is a little ironic that both Senator Kernot and Senator Watson are suggesting, through this amendment, that we put aside government moneys to fund legal centres. The people who staff it will have to be paid as lawyers. That may detract from the development of advice givers from other areas. However, that is not the main reason why we oppose the amendment.

Senator Kernot was quite clever in her wording when she said that the amendment encapsulates the recommendations from the committee. It certainly does that but it also goes beyond what the committee recommended. It certainly encapsulates it but it does a little more than the committee recommended. The committee recommended that the government consider supporting the establishment of an independent superannuation consumer advisory service by way of grants from consolidated revenue over three years. The government has given that undertaking in response to the committee's recommendations. It will consider that.

TALK.START.PARA: —But now you have to report back.

—The opposition can be somewhat sceptical about this consideration, but there are important reasons why we should not be darting in now to fund a legal service when we are not exactly sure of what the demand for it will be or how it should develop. There are important reasons for actually analysing how the legal centre, if it is to go ahead, will operate and what an appropriate level of funding would be.

PARA.TAB: We in the government take the view that we will be in a much better position to analyse the creation of a legal centre when we are closer to the date of operation of the tribunal—1 July next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's all we are asking for.

—The coalition is certainly limiting our flexibility to approach this matter a little closer to the date of the tribunal operating, which is 1 July next year. For that reason, we cannot support it. Frankly, this is a budgetary matter—
—There's no money.

—The coalition wants some money; it should be honest about it. It would not be pushing for this if it did not want the money. It either wants the money or it does not. Senator Watson is either fair dinkum about the amendment or he is not, or he is supporting the Democrats for some other reason that I am not aware of. But I am sure the coalition wants the money. I do not cast any aspersion in making that comment.

PARA.TAB: The coalition clearly wants the money and the government is prepared to evaluate and work out what moneys should be paid, in what form and over what time. Therefore, we cannot support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate's position would certainly have been a lot easier and maybe Senator Kernot's amendment would not have been necessary had the government's response to the Senate select committee's ninth report on these bills been available before we discussed these bills. It should have been circulated. There are some unofficial comments about what the government intends to do. Given the fact that the report has not been put down and given the doubt about how adequately the government is going to respond not only to this but also to other issues, I still think that we should press this amendment because it is not an appropriation of money.

PARA.TAB: All the government has to do is report back to the parliament and say why it has not complied with the regulation. We will then examine that in light of the worth of its argument. We are reasonable people. Our side of politics is not keen on throwing a lot of money around. In terms of the democratic process, I think it is a good procedure, particularly in view of the fact that we do not have the government's response to the recommendations put forward in this very important document.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to address a couple of the comments that Senator Sherry made. The fact is that the community legal services are not staffed entirely by lawyers. A lot of people work there as volunteers; they give their advice and information for free. I think honourable senators would find that those lawyers who do work there actually work for a very low salary. That is because the sorts of people who work there are motivated by values other than salary scale. They actually care about consumers having access to low-cost, independent advice.

PARA.TAB: The government has the ISC to give it advice. The superannuation funds have ASFA. At this point, consumers do not have anybody in particular. I think that will come because we all know how important superannuation and superannuation funds are going to become. It paints a false picture of all of those dedicated people who work in community legal centres to put them, first and foremost, as money hungry lawyers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I want to respond to the comment by Senator Watson that the opposition is not keen to throw money around. He might have that quoted back to him at the appropriate time in the future. I am sure that the Australian Democrats will be interested to know what his definition of not throwing a lot of money around is.

PARA.TAB: In response to that last comment of Senator Kernot, I know that in the legal centres there are many dedicated people who are not legal practitioners, as well as legal practitioners who do work for far below the market rate. But the fact is that lawyers encourage lawyers. I have seen it happen. I am not saying that the legal centres themselves do this. But, as soon as a consumer starts employing lawyers, the other party will run off and get a QC. I have seen it happen in the industrial systems, where lawyers are permitted. I have great reservations about the involvement of lawyers. But that is not the main reason why we oppose the amendment.

Senator Kernot said that consumers need assistance. They do. That is why we are setting up the tribunal. Nothing exists at the moment for the consumer, except common law remedy, which we all know is totally unsatisfactory. So we are setting up an independent tribunal with a full-time chairperson. There will be other part-time tribunal members. There will be a full-time secretariat of 18 people and three-quarters of a million dollars will be allocated per annum. That is in the bill. It is designed to protect and to respond to consumer interests in a very cost-effective way.

I reject the argument that consumers are not being helped. They are being helped. It is my hope that, with the development of the independent tribunal, we will see a very active development of consumer representation, where necessary. It is certainly my hope that those representatives are not lawyers in any sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue is not the adequacy or weaknesses of the tribunal. The issue is essentially to ensure that consumers are given the confidence in terms of having an independent party assist them to prepare their cases before the tribunal. Once that case has been prepared, the legal service can then back off. I think it can be a very cost-effective and efficient method of providing a degree of justice to a lot of people who would otherwise be denied.

PARA.TAB: The tribunal will provide an alternative to the secretariat which operates through the ISC, and that will assist consumers. But there will be a number of people in society who will be rather reticent about going to the regulator because of a perceived difficulty as to whether they will get the same degree of justice, information and support as they would going to an independent party. I would say to Senator Sherry that the government could well find itself saving a considerable amount of money because the resources required within the ISC secretariat to assist consumers will be so much less if consumers have an alternative, cheaply funded body to go to other than the ISC. Whichever way we look at it, we are providing an alternative and a real measure of support to consumers in a very cost-effective way.
Amendment agreed to.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 23, page 9, after subclause (1) insert the following subclause:
"(1A) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(a) the meaning of disability in relation to a person is extended to include a limited ability to speak, read or write English.".

The effect of these two amendments will be to slightly expand the right of representation before the tribunal in two situations, firstly, where the complainant has a limited ability to speak, read or write English and, secondly, where the tribunal regards it as `desirable in all the circumstances in the interests of fairness'. The reason for these amendments is that we are concerned that trustees of funds, particularly larger funds, will be in a fundamentally stronger position vis-a-vis complainants in the tribunal. They will be trained in the procedures of the act. In many cases they will be full-time trustees, whereas the complainants will be ordinary Australians doing what they ordinarily do.

PARA.TAB: While we recognise and support the need to keep the tribunal processes simple, we still believe that the tribunal must take a broad approach to the issue of representation. Where the complainant clearly does not understand the legal situation or is largely innumerate, for example, the tribunal should insist in the interests of fairness that they get representation. Again, consumer groups regard this amendment as the absolute minimum requirement to improve what I think the government has acknowledged in its legislation, but which just does not go far enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal-National Party opposition will not be supporting these amendments. We believe that the legislation contains adequate support for the issues that Senator Kernot raised in terms of providing an interpreter service and other necessary support services. In view of the fact that there are adequate provisions already in the legislation, we believe that the two Democrat amendments, although fair, are unnecessary in terms of the adequacy of the coverage of the current provisions.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that where trustees are other than members of a fund—they could be representatives of the ACTU—this amendment is no reflection on their capabilities. Some of the best performing funds in Australia are those that are run on the basis of trade union-type representatives representing employees. There is no doubt about that, and that is widely recognised. However, as these bills are all about prudential standards, we believe that there is no better auditor of a superannuation fund than a person who is a member of that fund. We are suggesting that at least one member who represents the employees' interests shall be a member of that superannuation fund.

PARA.TAB: I think that honourable members will find that in most circumstances that is the case. It makes good sense that there is at least one trustee who is a member, and maybe more. This does not preclude an employee who is a member of the fund from being a trade unionist. These bills are all about safeguards and prudential controls. It should not be forgotten that there are very high standards required of trustees. They can be sued by other members of the fund who believe the trustees have not acted in their best interests. There could be circumstances where the trustees make a decision that does not suit the performance of the fund and that could cause difficulties.

These amendments provide that at least one of the trustees representing the employees' interests shall be a member of the fund, rather than an outside person. I think this will enhance the prudential standards and controls that operate. The amendment is moved with the highest motive in terms of trying to add another notch or ratchet to the prudential standards or controls that apply to superannuation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Given that the development of the national rail infrastructure is essential to the future viability of rail as an alternative form of long distance transport, can the minister advise the Senate of what progress has been made in upgrading the national rail network?

—I am pleased to advise honourable senators that the establishment of a national rail network is progressing well. On 8 November I was present at the embarkation of the first train crewed by National Rail staff from Melbourne to Adelaide. The new enterprise agreement negotiated by National Rail and rail unions offers greater operational flexibility in train crewing such that the number of crew changes between Melbourne and Adelaide has been reduced from three to one.

PARA.TAB: While interstate freight activities and assets are being progressively transferred from the state rail systems, the federal government is continuing to upgrade the national rail infrastructure through its $450 million One Nation investment program. While the program suffered initial delays as the states came to terms with the concept of making substantial investments in their rail freight infrastructure, most projects are now under way or completed.

Projects already completed include: the rehabilitation of the Goulburn River bridge on the Sydney-Melbourne line; most of the 30 new bridges replacing the old timber structures on the Sydney-Brisbane line; and the raising of height clearances between Adelaide and Kalgoorlie.

The $5 million road connection from the Melbourne rail freight terminal to the Port of Melbourne, an extremely important intermodal link, will be completed in December this year. Work is also well under way on the $18 million upgrade of the Melbourne rail freight terminal itself. The remaining bridge replacement projects on the Sydney-Brisbane rail line and the standard gauge link to the Port of Brisbane are also well under way, while works have now commenced on the $8 million Adelaide-Outer Harbour project and other upgrading projects between Sydney and Melbourne.

On the $153 million Melbourne-Adelaide standardisation project, construction has commenced on the new Melbourne-Geelong section and gauge convertible sleepers are being inserted on the Adelaide-Victorian border section of the Melbourne-Adelaide line. Tenders have now been called for the supply of 100,000 concrete sleepers for the Melbourne-Geelong section. Site work for the new concrete sleeper plant at South Grafton is almost complete. This plant is being built as a direct result of the demand created by the One Nation program. Seventeen-and-a-half thousand tonnes of rail to be used for various projects on the network are currently being supplied with the order to be completely filled by March 1994. Tenders have been called or are about to be called for the construction of most of the remaining projects.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I know those opposite never want to hear good news.

PARA.TAB: On current schedules, by April 1995 thousands of construction workers will have created an upgraded standard gauge network running from the port of Brisbane to the port of Fremantle. This major achievement on the One Nation program, in combination with the $800 million investment program which is now under way within National Rail itself, will ensure that rail will be able to actively participate in the intensively competitive market for interstate freight.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What impact has the `Celebrate Australia' promotion had in Japan? What tangible benefits to Australia are expected to flow from it?

—`Celebrate Australia' is the largest promotion of its type undertaken by Australia with nearly 100 events in 33 cities throughout Japan. Its estimated value will be about $40 million. The promotion represents a major collaborative effort between federal and state departments, agencies and business.

PARA.TAB: For a relatively modest outlay, the Australian government has succeeded in developing a major event which will generate widespread interest in and publicity for Australia in Japan and help promote commercial opportunities and update Australia's image. DFAT has contributed about $1.5 million to coordinate the promotion and to fund core cultural events, including the Australian Ballet, Playbox Theatre, the Aboriginal and Islander Dance Theatre and contemporary jewellery and photography exhibitions.

`Celebrate Australia' has been widely covered by the Japanese media. Considerable attention was received as a result of the promotion being launched by the Crown Prince and Princess. The Japanese broadcaster, NHK, featured an Australian special on its main satellite channel on 3 November which ran for more than five hours.

Although `Celebrate Australia' still has another fortnight to run, there has already been substantial interest throughout Japan in the cultural events and promotional activities. As well as the cultural activities, the promotion has strong commercial and trade focus designed to penetrate the Japanese market. These activities include a major push by Export Music Australia. Promotion of a wide range of goods has also occurred in the Daimaru department stores.

`Celebrate Australia' also encompasses a wide spectrum of activities, including seminars and lectures designed to broaden awareness of Australian excellence in such fields as science and education. The promotion is designed to raise Australia's profile and, in particular, increase Japanese recognition of the quality and availability of Australian products and services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories aware that the South Australian government is hell-bent on building a bridge to Hindmarsh Island in the lower Murray in South Australia? Is the minister aware that such a bridge will substantially increase the impact on the very important wetland areas of the lower Murray, Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert and that these important areas are protected under the international agreements Ramsar, JAMBA and CAMBA? Is the minister also aware that the South Australian Parliamentary Standing Committee on Environment, Resources and Development, which contains three government members, recommended that the bridge not be built? Will the minister act, as she has already done in the case of the Creery Wetland in the Mandurah Estuary in Western Australia, to protect these South Australian wetlands of international significance and use her powers to put an immediate stop to the construction of the bridge to Hindmarsh Island?
—I have been provided with information by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, on this matter.
—Has it been checked out by the Auditor-General?

—It would not have to be with Senator Kemp's brains, I suppose. The water surrounding Hindmarsh Island, which is located at the mouth of the Murray River, was listed by Australia as a wetland of international importance under the Ramsar convention of 1985. The wetlands of the island are also regarded as important for a number of species listed under the bilateral migratory birds agreements that Australia has with Japan and China.

PARA.TAB: Subsequent to the proponents' environmental impact statement in 1990, public concerns were raised about, amongst other things, the lack of infrastructure for managing increased visitation to the island's valuable wetlands. In October 1993, the environment, resource and development committee of the parliament of South Australia released its inquiry into the Hindmarsh Island bridge project. Amongst its recommendations were that the South Australian government should reassess the need for a bridge and that more emphasis should be placed on the environmental aspects of the proposal. Senator Coulter has already alluded to that report.

Advice to the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency is that there are no aspects of the bridge proposal with a potential to trigger Commonwealth environmental assessment legislation. In Australia the Ramsar Convention and the migratory birds agreement are implemented by the state and territory governments in cooperation with the federal government.

The Commonwealth, in effect, delegates responsibility to the states or territories with respect to the management of sites recognised under the Ramsar Convention. However, Mrs Kelly advises that the federal government will consult with the South Australian government to consider the implications for changed management of the island, particularly taking into account the potential for increased visitation to the island. Subject to any decision by the South Australian government, the federal and state governments will cooperate in this approach. I spoke to Mrs Kelly just before question time, because Senator Coulter had given notice of this question, and she again emphasised that she will be having consultations with the South Australian government about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to a recent study of Aboriginal heritage sites on the Burrup Peninsula, in the north-west of Western Australia, which was funded under the National Estate grants program and also to a land use planning study carried out by the Western Australian Department of Resources Development. What is the current status of the proposal to extend the National Estate listed areas on the Burrup Peninsula? Is the minister aware that the Department of Resources Development study commits the state government to the development of an industrial transport corridor through present and proposed National Estate listed areas? Is the minister aware that a report commissioned by the Dampier Port Authority in 1989 concluded that there are other sites better suited on engineering grounds to industrial development than the Conzinc Bay area, which lies within the National Estate area? What action will the Commonwealth government take to protect these areas of important cultural and natural heritage?

—I have been provided with information from Mrs Kelly. I think Senator Margetts indicated previously to Mrs Kelly that she was going to ask this question.In relation to part one of the question, I am advised that the report of the recent study has been received by the Australian Heritage Commission. The report recommends an extension of the areas currently listed in the register of the National Estate. The recommendation is currently being assessed by the commission.

PARA.TAB: The answer to part two is that the minister is aware of the proposal for a transport corridor and that the proposed corridor route travels through an area currently listed in the register of the National Estate. The answer to part three is that the minister is not aware of such a report.

The answer to part four of the question is that, under subsections (1) and (2) of section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, Commonwealth ministers, departments and authorities are obliged not to take any action that would adversely affect part of the National Estate unless there is no feasible and prudent alternative. If there is no such alternative, then all measures that can be reasonably taken to minimise the adverse effect are to be taken.

Listing in the register of the National Estate has no legal effect on the actions of state governments, local governments or private individuals or corporations within the state. Only the Commonwealth is directly affected under the commission's act. At this stage the minister is unaware of any Commonwealth involvement in this project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. If, as seems obvious from the information, there is an alternative, does that mean there is a guaranteed indication that action may or will be taken on this matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. At an estimates committee hearing on Monday night, I asked the minister whether a BASI officer had advised him that a CAA officer had been aware of the removal of the autopilot from the plane which crashed at Young. The minister's reply was `no'. I now refer the minister and the Senate to draft minutes of his meeting with the CAA board on 27 October. These minutes report:

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Collins said that the BASI reports had raised a number of serious issues, questions he felt should be answered by the authority. These included that: . . . a BASI officer had that morning advised that a CAA officer had known that the autopilot had been removed from the aircraft. Is this correct?
Did the minister lie to the Senate estimates committee or is he planning to alter the minutes of the meeting with the CAA?

TALK.START.PARA: —The evidence which I gave to the estimates committee is absolutely correct. I am happy to provide Senator Ian Macdonald—in fact, I will immediately after question time today—with a copy of the written advice I received from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which absolutely confirms the advice which I gave the estimates committee.

PARA.TAB: What happened at the time of this incident—and I have to say that it happens after every incident, and not surprisingly—was that a great deal of unsubstantiated rumour and assertions were made. Unfortunately, a number—

TALK.START.PARA: —You told me `no'.
—And that answer is correct. A number of—
—What about these minutes?

—I am not responsible for the minutes of the CAA board. At the time of that board meeting, there was a whole host of unsubstantiated assertions and claims being made, which is common after these incidents. I say again, I am happy to provide the advice I got from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and I will do it after question time.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, these unsubstantiated assertions were complicated by the fact that a number of erroneous press reports also occurred containing these assertions. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has advised that the interim recommendations that it made concerning the aircraft's autopilot do not state that the CAA permitted the aircraft to fly with the autopilot removed, nor does the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation advice and the recommendations state that the CAA was aware that the autopilot had been removed from the aircraft.

What was being discussed—and I am happy to assert this—was that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, as it has an obligation to do, was following up every piece of corridor gossip and every unsubstantiated assertion that was being run at the time. It has an obligation to run every one of them to ground. An assertion had been made, and Senator Macdonald is well aware of it, that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation was investigating. I reported to the board, accurately, that this was the case. It subsequently proved to be false, as Senator Macdonald well knows, and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation formal advice to me—which I will give Senator Ian Macdonald a copy of immediately after question time—substantiated that fact, so he should not rely on corridor gossip.

The assertions were made; that is correct. The assertions were canvassed at the CAA board meeting and it was completely responsible of me as the minister to raise them. I quite happily confirm that I personally went to the board. The assertions were unsubstantiated. That is the point Senator Macdonald happily skips over.

News reports actually misquoted the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and a report appeared in the Canberra Times on 29 October which in fact did that. It misquoted the recommendations. The CAA has confirmed that on the information available to the authority it was not aware of the removal of that autopilot from the aircraft, nor did it authorise that removal. That is absolutely consistent with the advice that I received from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister deny that on Monday night he told me that a BASI officer not had advised him that a CAA officer had been aware of the removal of the autopilot? Does he deny that he told me that? He should not, because I have the transcript. The minutes from the CAA claim that the minister said `a BASI officer had that morning advised that a CAA officer had known that the autopilot had been removed'. Does the minister deny that he told the CAA that on the morning of 27 October? If not, those two answers are contradictory and the minister lied to me at the Senate estimates committee meeting.

—I ask Senator Ian Macdonald to refer to the Hansard. Yes, I discussed with the board the assertions that were being made by all kinds of people who were ringing up the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and the CAA, and appearing on television.The facts are: in terms of the formal advice BASI gives me, it does not rely on corridor gossip which, of course, is what Senator Macdonald is dealing with; it does not rely on unsubstantiated assertions. When those allegations were investigated by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation they were found to be false. The advice given to me was that they were. The CAA has confirmed that it neither authorised the removal of that autopilot, nor was aware of its removal.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs been drawn to comments by the New South Wales Minister for Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Photios, criticising the government's policy on the Cambodian boat people and describing the conditions at the Villawood detention facility as appalling? Is it true, as Mr Photios claims, that the Cambodians are denied or provided with limited medical care, education, torture and rape counselling and, particularly, women's health services? Furthermore, do Mr Photios's criticisms of the recently announced Cambodian special assistance category accurately reflect the government's attempts to find a solution to this complex problem?

—Immigration and ethnic affairs is an area of great sensitivity and complexity. I believe that it needs to be addressed responsibly and with care and thoughtfulness. Unfortunately, in the last 24 hours in the New South Wales parliament we have had an example of the completely opposite approach to a very sensitive issue. That occurred in an outburst from the New South Wales Minister for Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Photios.

PARA.TAB: Mr Photios was addressing the question of the boat people. I believe that his comments can be most generously described as inaccurate, indulgent and irresponsible. Fundamentally, Mr Photios's comments were peppered with outrageous inaccuracies. He claimed that the conditions in the Villawood detention centre could best be described as appalling. The government has been more than forthcoming in respect of the conditions in detention facilities. Our submission to the joint standing committee inquiry into detention demonstrates this.

It is a pity that Mr Photios did not bother to address the issue accurately. If he had done so, perhaps he would not have stated that only limited health services, and virtually no women's health care, were available at Villawood. The fact is that a centre nurse is on duty six days a week and a doctor visits the centre twice a day. Basic dental and optical care are provided.

Had the New South Wales minister even checked with his colleagues, he would have discovered that the New South Wales Department of Health's child-care service visits Villawood regularly to provide antenatal services to mothers. Since July this year a gender specific medical program has been operating—a program which now formalises a previously informal arrangement.

Further, and contrary to Mr Photios's claims, the centre provides educational facilities, including English language classes, to all detainees—children and adults. It is grossly untrue to suggest that the children have been denied education. It is also grossly untrue to suggest that detainees' access to religious services is limited. Religious workers from the major Christian denominations attend the centre on a daily basis and Buddhist monks usually attend the centre on culturally significant days.

Probably the most outrageous part of Mr Photios's statement yesterday was that counselling for victims of torture and rape is virtually non-existent. This is not only grossly wrong but also it illustrates Mr Photios's preparedness to exploit the most vulnerable of these people for his own political ends. A full range of torture and trauma counselling and treatment is available to the detainees. That range includes the admirable work of a group of psychiatrists led by Dr Maria Bashir and the service for the treatment and rehabilitation of torture and trauma survivors.

Mr Photios did not stop at just spreading inaccuracies. In his typically opportunistic fashion, he accused the Labor Party of being anti-migrant. This comes from a member of a party which says that probably all immigrant applicants, including boat people, should be removed from the jurisdiction of the ADJR. As a consequence, the access to the courts—which the constitution guarantees them—would be denied to them. Mr Photios's confusion went even further in a pretty broad statement that he made in the parliament.

His statements are irresponsible. They do not add to the constructive nature of the debate as is necessary in this area. They undermine the special program announced last fortnight for Cambodians, not only those in detention but also those with families in Australia. It is irresponsible behaviour and I believe that it is divisive not only to the New South Wales community and to the ethnic communities within that, but also to the broader Australian community. He is acting as a parasite on the Australian public—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: I ask that the minister withdraw that improper imputation on the reputation of Mr Photios immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Yes. It is clearly unparliamentary and I ask Senator Bolkus to withdraw it. I also remind opposition senators that it is unparliamentary to make the comment that was made earlier today that the minister lied.

—I withdraw, Mr President. In the interests of Australia, I believe this state minister should desist from this divisive political game. He should not be allowed to continue in this way, feeding off the problems of Australian communities—ethnic and otherwise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I remind the minister that on 26 October he told the Senate:

QUESTION.PARA: We cannot continue to have private health insurance bleed in the way that it has in past years because this . . . increase(s) the strain on the public health system.

Will the minister inform this chamber how he will lessen the strain on the public health system when the Prime Minister continues to refuse his requests for him and his family to take out private health cover? Does the minister agree that the current health system would effectively collapse if middle and high income earners followed the Prime Minister's selfish example?

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that last week, when I was in Perth serving the interests of the people, the Prime Minister made some comments on the question of private health insurance. In accordance with the Prime Minister's style and tradition, those comments were robust and to the point. I note that the Prime Minister says he will take a lot of convincing.

PARA.TAB: I will not be trying to convince him to take out private health insurance because I always intended to put up a proposition that had an option. In any event, though, I have always been pretty reasonable at convincing. I intend to go in there and do my best to convince him and, of course, the cabinet and indeed the party that the program of reforms, of which a higher levy is but one, is worth while. I know there will be considerable opposition to various parts of that proposal, so I will be taking a view to the Prime Minister and my party and hopefully I will convince them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer to a joint statement issued last month by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Mr Griffiths, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, launching Australia's biggest export drive designed to persuade the Asia-Pacific region to buy pure Australian food. I also refer to the fact that the minister recently attended ANUGA, the international food trade fair in Germany. Is the minister able to advise the Senate on ways in which Australian food exporters can look to expand additional export opportunities in value added processed foods?

—I was able to represent the Australian government at the international food trade fair in Germany about a month ago. The German acronym for that trade fair is ANUGA. It is the world's biggest food and beverages trade fair, with over 6,000 exhibitors and 200,000 trade visitors from all around the world. In view of the government's policy for the agri-food sector in getting better value for processed food exports from Australia, it is a very important venue.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that the agri-food sector is our largest manufacturing industry in Australia. There are 170,000 Australians employed in that industry which has an annual turnover of $30 billion a year. We estimate that by the year 2000 our processed food exports will total about $7 billion. Already value added food exports exceed imports, $3 billion to $2.4 billion.

At ANUGA it was interesting to see the presentations that various countries had. Australia was represented by a presentation on which we spent $350,000. By comparison, New Zealand spent $1.7 million on its trade exhibit at the fair. The amount of money spent was reflected in the size and style of the exhibits.

I congratulate those Australian private firms which were at the fair and committed resources in conjunction with Austrade. One of the most disappointing things was to see the impact that present European Community policy on meat quotas has on Australian industry. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation had a separate stand with several private exhibiters. In one morning every one of those exhibiters said that they had to turn down orders from Europe for their products because they could not get access to the European market because of the quota system. All the European buyers said the quality and presentation of our meat was absolutely first rate and that they would be only too delighted to buy it but, unfortunately, as we know, the European Community has quota limits and we cannot get into those markets because of those quotas.

The other aspect that was positive was that this was not just a European fair; it was a world fair. Although we were stymied on sales to the European Community, the livestock corporation and its exhibiters got very good business from customers in the Middle East. All exhibiters at the Meat and Livestock Corporation stand within a day were writing very good business for exports to the Middle East.

I will certainly be taking up with my colleagues Senator Cook and Minister Griffiths the need for Australia to put more resources into the presentation at ANUGA and encourage more Australian industries to be represented. This is the major world trade fair in food and beverages. It obviously writes a lot of business for countries and companies around the world. I think we ought to lift our game and put the resources in to benefit Australian industry. It certainly would be in tune with the government's policy for the Agrifood Council to develop high value food exports from Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the statement of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs reported in the Australian on 5 November. He forecast a form of self-government for the Torres Strait islands by the year 2001. He said further that he would propose that the Prime Minister suggest to the Queensland Premier that they hold talks about regional self-government. What does the government mean by regional self-government? Does the minister mean regional self-government based on the model of the Cook Islands as suggested in the same article by the Island Coordinating Council chairman, Gaetano Lui? Did the minister have the backing of the Prime Minister and government when he made these statements on self-government to the people of the Torres Strait Islands? Has the minister approached the Prime Minister to hold his proposed suggested talks with Mr Goss on regional self-government for the Torres Strait?

—The Island Coordinating Council of the Torres Strait proposed a move towards self-government for the Torres Strait by the year 2001. This is a long-term aspiration and the substantial details of the proposals by Torres Strait islanders have not yet been put forward. The commonwealth has therefore not agreed to any details of such proposals, but believes the aspirations of the Torres Strait islanders must be taken seriously. Further consideration and discussion should occur between the Island Coordinating Council, the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has written to both Premier Goss and the Island Coordinating Council to propose a preliminary meeting of officials. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has consistently put on the public record his view that any move towards greater self-government cannot be rushed and needs to be the subject of a sustained detailed discussion with all interested groups in the Torres Strait.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that detailed answer. Has the minister considered the foreign affairs repercussions between Papua New Guinea and Australia in relation to regional self-government?

—The matter mentioned by Senator Boswell is just one of many issues that would have to be considered. Clearly, given the boundary demarcation that has been agreed on, that would be a major factor for us to consider. There are all sorts of immigration and other matters that have to be taken into account, even the minority interest, because at least 20 per cent of the population in that area did not originally come from the Torres Strait. So there are many complex issues that would have to be discussed before this matter could be brought to fruition one way or the other, including the philosophical concept of whether it is the correct thing to do even before we settle the details.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the minister's recently circulated draft cabinet submission on the proposed east coast armaments complex, ECAC, which puts forward Jervis Bay and Twofold Bay as two site options. Can the minister confirm that to build ECAC at Twofold Bay would require the woodchip mill to be entirely relocated or regularly shut down while the armament wharf was in operation? What are the estimated costs of compensation which would have to be paid to Harris-Daishowa if ECAC were built at Twofold Bay? Why was Gladstone eliminated as an ECAC option, given that a possible mainland site has been identified north of the town which could cut construction and operating costs?

—Beyond even a draft cabinet submission, I have lodged a cabinet submission on this matter. I do not intend to canvass the issues contained within that submission here. I never have in the past and I will not in the future. As soon as a decision is made by cabinet, Senator Woodley and the parliament will be informed.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. How many airports are there in Australia which receive international passenger flights?
—I do not know.
—That is the first time I have ever heard you say that!

—No, it is not actually. I can remember saying it on more than one occasion in question time. I am never afraid to say that I do not know if I do not know. From time to time I designate a range of airports as international airports—for example, the Broome airport and other airports. In fact, I think I have designated two or three in the last 12 months.
—Can I guess the supplementary?
—I know what the supplementary question will be. The answer is: 25 minutes flying time from Sydney.

PARA.TAB: These airports are designated as international airports in order for them to take charter international flights. So we would have to distinguish between the mainstream airports around Australia that regularly receive international flights and those that are designated international airports, because there are a great many designated international airports that do not receive regular RPT and international services. I will provide that information to Senator Reid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I could not bring myself to disappoint the minister. I will be happy to have the answer in the form of two lists; that will be very useful. At the same time could the minister let me know which other countries do not have an international airport at their national capital?

—I will not be tied down to this, but I think there would not be too many that had major international airports within 25 minutes flying time of the capital and extensive commuter services between the two airports that operate about 20 times a day. But I will find out the answer to that question for Senator Reid.

—Because of my interest in and support for the aerodrome local ownership plan program, I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the minister provide the Senate with a report on progress being made in completing the transfer of aerodromes to local ownership under the Commonwealth's aerodrome local ownership plan program?

—I am pleased to report that all 234 aerodromes participating in the aerodrome local ownership plan, known commonly as ALOP, have now withdrawn from that plan. They are now in the hands of their local authorities, which is where they should be. Twenty-eight of the 30 Commonwealth airports have also been transferred at this stage to alternative ownership.

PARA.TAB: In this transfer process, the Commonwealth—I must say, to the great benefit of many local communities around Australia—has provided more than $64 million in grants and social benefit subsidies to enable the completion of this program. The complete withdrawal of the whole 234 aerodromes has now been completed and the aerodromes have been transferred to local ownership. It has been a major achievement of the Aviation Division of the Department of Transport and Communications to complete such an extensive program of transfers in such a time frame and completely within the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, because of the attention that is being given to questions relating to Aboriginal people, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware whether, as part of the handover of aerodromes in the far north of Queensland, training programs are being provided to assist Aboriginal communities maintain and operate these aerodromes?

—Yes, that is happening. The department of transport, in conjunction with ATSIC, is providing training for reporting officers from a number of far north Queensland aerodromes to assist with the future maintenance and day-to-day operations of those aerodromes. For example, Aurukun, Hopevale, Mornington Island and Palm Island are just some of a number of the communities that have officers under training at the moment. A two-day training course is to be held in Cairns this week. The Cairns Port Authority has kindly offered its facilities at the Cairns airport to help the participants in this training program take the opportunity to participate in a real life on-site airport training scheme.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns fringe benefits tax. I refer the minister to the recent Federal Court decision involving the National Australia Bank whereby employer-funded taxi travel after hours has been regarded as a fringe benefit and subject to the fringe benefits tax. I remind the minister that this may mean that some employer-funded taxi travel, when employees have to commute to and from work outside normal hours, could cause some problems. I ask: will not the decision add to the level of costs of employing people, especially women? Is the minister not concerned that this lack of tax recognition of employer-funded taxi travel will place many females who need to travel home late at risk if they are forced to use public transport? Will the government as a matter of social conscience introduce legislation to remove any doubt that employer-funded taxi travel should not incur fringe benefits?
—Order! The time has expired.

—The government is aware of the concerns regarding this matter. We are examining the implications of the recent court decision concerning the application of FBT in this area. So it is under examination. There are some points that I think we should make in case this generates unnecessary fear and concern amongst people and perhaps leads to unnecessary changes in practices. It is important to note that there is already an exemption from FBT where an employer pays taxi fares for an employee on an infrequent and irregular basis; that is, where the employee is unexpectedly required to work late. So circumstances in which it would not have been possible for people to make other arrangements because they did not have advance notice are already exempt from FBT. My advice is that that is not changed by the National Australia Bank decision.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that we do not send the wrong message to employers. I am advised that where they are acting in accordance with that exemption, which is where the problem to which Senator Watson refers could most often arise, there is already and continues to be an exemption. Of course, FBT does not apply in the case of FBT-exempt employers. Many areas of large volume female employment in the shift area would come into that category. There are a number of circumstances in which, even if the most extreme interpretation of the National Australia Bank decision were to be taken, exemption would apply. Nevertheless, there are some concerns being expressed with regard to the possible implications of the Federal Court decision. The government has that under examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What degree of frequency or infrequency does the tax office regard as, in its terminology, `infrequent'?
—To quote a higher authority, Mr President, I do not know. But I will seek to find out and advise Senator Watson.
—I address my question to the Minister for Defence. Are the Australian Defence Industries now operating profitably? How is the company contributing to Australia's economic growth?
—Mr President—
—Tell us about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.

—Senator Crichton-Browne asks me to remind him about the ordnance factory in Bendigo, which he and one of his Western Australian colleagues—fortunately departed from this chamber—tried to close at the orders of his Prime Minister. It is now operating very profitably.
—There was no order from the Prime Minister.

—Sorry, there was no order; it was a conjunction of dull minds. The 1992-93 outcome for Australian Defence Industries is welcome. It is a clear demonstration of the rewards being reaped by decisions of government made in the late 1980s. It must be remembered that most of the activities carried out by ADI were previously done as part of Commonwealth departments, with an annual bill to the taxpayer of $250 million a year. When one looks at the figures announced recently, in that context they are particularly pleasing.It is also an example of how management, staff and unions can work together to restructure an environment that was outdated and not suited to commercial-type practices. The change has been substantial. The areas that ADI was required to take on were difficult ones and not traditionally profit oriented.
—How much public money was involved?

—Senator Hill interjects. When he asks his first defence question in this chamber as shadow minister I want everyone to be quiet so they can listen to him. But he has not done it since April this year. As shadow minister he has not asked one question on defence.

PARA.TAB: The annual turnover for the company now is approaching $460 million. It is encouraging to see that ADI has reported an operating profit of $34.4 million in 1992-93. This continues on the good results in the previous years of $33.6 million in 1991-92 and $29.4 million in 1990-91, the first full year of business.

ADI is now one of Australia's prominent defence firms. It has won contracts overseas as well as in Australia. It is a fully commercial operation, independently run by a board of directors. It has won contracts on its own merits and through its own hard work. The company is involved in a variety of defence products. ADI is part of a consortium bidding for the navy's coastal minehunter project. It produces sophisticated weapons targeting systems. It manufactures high quality, high tolerance equipment for the Collins class submarine.

Earlier this year ADI and the Department of Defence signed a $1.4 billion ammunition contract covering the next 20 years. This will involve the construction of a $150 million ammunition plant at Benalla in Victoria. The new contract represents a substantial contribution to the nation's self-reliant defence posture at an affordable cost.

There are also spin-offs into other areas that have proved profitable for the company. These include the construction of Western Australia's first wind farm and the refurbishing of the massive turbines at the Tumut power stations. ADI is achieving what the government hoped it would achieve. It has turned a non-profitable business with inflexible, old-fashioned practices into a profit-making enterprise. The board, management and staff at ADI are to be congratulated on their progress and success in recent years. The company is aware that the government will consider the future of ADI in the new year and whether it will be retained as a government-owned enterprise. I think the fact that ADI has shown that it is a viable defence company in Australia is encouraging.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister confirm Mr Beazley's reported comments in the Sydney Morning Herald on 16 November that total new university places will be cut back to 1,500 places by 1996? Is the government's proposal to do this in the face of more than 40,000 qualified students consistently missing out on a place year after year an admission of the complete failure of the government's university new enrolment policy?

—The purpose of Mr Beazley's comments was to point out that it is very important that government devote resources to cover all areas of Australia and that one has to take into account the fact that in some areas of Australia the population is growing far more rapidly than in others. I understand that was the import of his speech.

PARA.TAB: He pointed out that Victoria, in particular, did not have a growing population—its population is almost stagnant, only slightly growing—compared with some areas in Queensland and Western Australia, where growth is more strong, and there may need to be a reallocation of resources to meet those trends. That is not an unusual thing in government; it has happened within cities. It will also happen now around Australia to make sure that all students have the appropriate opportunity to complete a tertiary education. I have not yet caught up with the full text of the speech. I will endeavour to do so and if I can add anything to the response to Senator Tierney's question I will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister obviously has not caught up with the text because he has missed the whole point of the question. I am not talking about redistribution around Australia to growth areas, which is very necessary. I am talking about the grand total of numbers dropping. I ask the minister for guidance on what I should advise my 14-year-old son Michael, who aspires to a university place in architecture in 1996, the year of this ALP government's savage cutbacks in new enrolments in total.

—I would suggest to Senator Tierney that I would be the last person in the world he should ask to give him some guidance as to the activities of his son. I am sure that he has inherited his father's genes and therefore his academic career will follow a particular course. But I did indicate at the end of my answer that I would endeavour to get some more information on the basis of his question. As I said, I have not read the speech. I read some newspaper reports of it. Having had previous discussions with Mr Beazley, I knew part of what he was thinking and I referred to that in my answer. As to the other parts, I will get Senator Tierney some information.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Trade. I refer to the priority which the Australian government has been affording expanding trade relations with China, as evidenced by the recent visit to Australia by the Chinese Minister for Trade and Economic Cooperation and the trade mission which Senator Cook took to China recently. Is the minister able to inform the Senate whether the government's efforts to date have produced results? If so, what have such results meant for Australian trade relations?

—I have not had the pleasure of raising this matter with Mr Mickey Kantor and Mr Zhu Rongji, unfortunately, but I am pleased to announce that from 1 January 1994 China has agreed to reduce the tariff on wool tops from 20 per cent to 15 per cent, the same rate as the tariff for greasy wool. This reduction, based on the 1992-93 figures for Australian sales of wool tops in China, should reduce the landing cost of Australian tops in China by some $5 million.

PARA.TAB: Specifically, the tariff reduction covers carded wool, wool tops and other combed wool. This breakthrough is the outcome of the Prime Minister's wool initiative taken during his visit to China in June and raised in bilateral discussions that Senator Cook and my colleague Mr Crean held with the Chinese Minister for Trade and Economic Cooperation, Madam Wu Yi, in October. China's decision reduces an impediment to further processing of wool within Australia and provides a basis for continued expansion of the Australian wool tops processing industry.

I consider this reduction in import duties to be an important first step in our overall strategy to increase access for Australian wool to China. The government will continue to seek from Chinese authorities reductions in other import barriers that apply to wool, including import licensing quotas and domestic taxes. Further discussions to improve the market access for Australian wool to China are likely in Geneva in December, in line with Australia's request of China, already made in the processes of China's accession to GATT.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Would the minister be kind enough to inform the Senate of the cost to Australian taxpayers of the Bendigo ordnance factory during the last 10 years of Labor government?

—The specific figures, before ADI was formed in 1989, no doubt can be drawn from the record. I know why Senator Crichton-Browne is so sensitive on this particular issue. He should remind himself of what the Labor government in 1983 inherited from the coalition government, which was all in favour of free enterprise, competition, and all the wonderful Liberal values. For 7 1/2 years it nurtured government factories in the defence area that were inefficient and incompetent and did absolutely nothing whatsoever about it. It had something like 20,000 employees working in what amounted to the most inefficient industries in this country.

PARA.TAB: What galls Senator Crichton-Browne is that this government has taken on these issues and turned these industries into a profitable area and an efficient organisation. I know that he is embarrassed by the fact that he went up to Bendigo in 1982 with Senator Martyr and tried to sell his sleazy propositions about closing down the Bendigo ordnance factory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I take offence at the word `sleazy'.
—Order! I am not so sure that the words were unparliamentary, but I ask for them to be withdrawn.

—I do not think I referred to Senator Crichton-Browne in that regard; I was talking about his proposals. I know that Senator Crichton-Browne would never fit that description, but I am sure that he was misguided enough to support what I called a sleazy proposal. However, if offence is taken, I withdraw.

PARA.TAB: I can see why Senator Crichton-Browne would want to raise the question today. There is a degree of jealousy in what has been achieved in this and other areas. I am sure that with diligent application and a fair amount of research, Senator Crichton-Browne would eventually in his heart of hearts agree that ADI has done a great job at Bendigo ordnance factory and at similar institutions that ADI controls around the country. As I stressed in my previous answer, these are not easy areas. These are not the quick profit areas; these are not areas in which it is easy to make a profit. ADI has done a great job. It is not without problems; it will face problems in the future, but I am sure that all honourable senators opposite would wish ADI well in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Notwithstanding my gross embarrassment, I wonder whether I might ask Senator Ray the same question in a different way. Putting aside his rhetoric, will he provide for the Senate the cost to taxpayers of the Bendigo ordinance factory for the 10 years of Labor government?

—That question is based on a false assumption that there is a cost to the taxpayer since we corporatised ADI in 1989. The question is a nonsense. What I promise to get for the honourable senator, if he would like, is the general cost to the taxpayer, as calculated, of the Bendigo ordinance factory until ADI was created. That is the only way in which that can be assessed. I will also pass on to Mr Bruce Reid, the honourable member for Bendigo, the honourable senator's opposition to ADI being at Bendigo and all the rest of it.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In recent times I have noticed an increase in the number of senators and advisers who are bringing mobile phones into the Senate chamber. I want to remind everybody that mobile phones are not permitted in the chamber, neither are they permitted in the galleries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to the Civil Aviation Authority and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. A few moments ago during question time, Senator Ian Macdonald said, `I have a copy of the Hansard from the Senate estimates committee on Monday night'. He then said, `Don't try to deny it because I have the Hansard here with me'. I have just checked with Hansard and the Secretary of Estimates Committee E, Mr Nugent. He advises me that no Hansard record has been made available to anyone—I myself tried to get it—to the knowledge of either Hansard or Mr Nugent. I ask Senator Ian Macdonald to table his copy of Hansard.
—Order! That is not a point of order. It is something that can be brought up in debate, so it does not require an answer. I am sure it will be dealt with in the debate.

Can I say to Senator Collins that what I said was that I have a transcript, and I have a transcript because I have a copy of the television recording of the Senate's hearing.
—That is not the Hansard.

—I did not say `Hansard'; I said `transcript'. The tape recording has been transcribed by my staff. If Senator Collins does not believe what is there—and I am quite happy to table this, or to table an unmarked copy—he can have a look at the videotape as well and do his own transcription. But I am sure Hansard will certify what my staff have done.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, on that note, I also seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the first page of what I say is a draft copy of the minutes of the CAA board meeting, headed `Meeting with the Minister for Transport and Communications'. I have made copies available to Senator Kernot and Senator Collins; I am sorry, I did not realise that Senator Margetts was still here. I seek leave to incorporate that document, a draft copy of the CAA minutes, as I call it.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: MEETING WITH MINISTER FOR TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

Senator Collins, Mr Lake and Mr Wolfe joined the meeting. The Chairman welcomed the Minister, and passed on the Board's thanks for his efforts in the safety regulation cost recovery issue, and for the work done on the Sydney airspace plan.

The Minister informed the Board that although he had intended to address the Board in general terms, that morning's Canberra Times article about the Monarch accident and information recently received from BASI would lead him to concentrate on that issue.

In the United States, mediation has been very successful in helping to resolve major environmental disputes. The results can last longer because a framework for constructive consultation is established.

The Greens have never agreed with all the recommendations of the Resource Assessment Commission, but we recognise that Resource Assessment Commission reports have invariably moved forward the debate on the real environmental issues. PARA.TAB: Other things are inadequate in the handling of research in this country. I want to focus on one of these today in the light of an article in this morning's Australian by Professor Roger Holmes, who is the deputy vice-chancellor of research at Griffith University. Professor Holmes's article, which is headed `Beazley must rethink funding formula', highlights one of the very unfortunate consequences of the 1993 budget and its effect on research infrastructure funding. He describes the budget as a wolf in sheep's clothing which will result in the further concentration of research dollars in this country in a smaller group of universities.

I am sure the Senate has heard of the plan of seven universities in this country to have the research dollars concentrated in their hands. What people have to realise is that two-thirds of the research money is already concentrated in these universities and what is now being proposed by these universities, aided and abetted by this government, is the further concentration of this funding.

It is seven years since the Dawkinisation of the universities in this country, when the whole system was turned upside down. Institutions that had very little in common were forced to move into mergers to meet some magic number; they could not be universities unless they had a certain number. Whole careers were thrown into states of confusion. People resigned and morale collapsed. What we now have from this government is a de facto admission that this whole policy has failed, despite the best efforts of the staff of universities to make it work in the face of very inappropriate government policy.

Having forced these institutions together, having moved staff and told them, `If you want a promotion in a university you have to have a research record'—so they turned their careers upside down and got into higher degrees and further research—the government, in effect, is now saying, `Hey, wait a minute. We are not going to do that now; we're going to go back to what we had in the binary system'.

This came out when I questioned one of the senior public servants, Mr Michael Gallagher, in the Senate estimates. He more or less admitted that if a university wanted to be a teaching university and do no research, it could do that. But he did not admit that the funding formula that the government is now applying will force many universities into that position and recreate the binary system we had before. Given how far we have come in recent years, this is a very backward step. This government stands condemned for this policy. It will be to the detriment of the reputation that Australia has built up in its universities.
