TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No.326, entitled An assessment of tax. This is the report of the committee's inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report concludes a two-year investigation by the committee into the administration of one of this country's largest and most significant institutions. For probably the first time in Australia a parliamentary committee has extensively investigated the manner in which income tax is collected. The inquiry was undertaken in recognition of the enormous changes in all aspects of the Australian Taxation Office and tax administration commenced at the beginning of the 1980s under the banner of modernisation.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry was commenced during the previous parliament under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Barton, Mr Punch. The committee accepted 128 public submissions, accounting for over 5,000 pages of evidence from ordinary taxpayers, academics, taxpayer agents, industry representatives, accounting and legal professionals, officers of the Taxation Office, senior tax office management and many others. In addition, it received more that 40 exhibits and considered a number of confidential documents.

The committee's report is a comprehensive assessment of the administration of the Taxation Office. While it is critical where necessary, it also recognises and commends the office for its many innovative and positive achievements, particularly in the areas of modernisation, self-assessment, personnel management and revenue collection. It also makes 148 recommendations, some of which I will now address.

In regard to legislative framework, in evaluating the tax office's performance, the committee has considered the efficiency of administering the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The committee has recognised that which must be painfully obvious to all in this parliament and, I would have to say, probably to all taxpayers in Australia—that the act is long overdue for redrafting.

The resolve to simplify the act must come from the parliament. A commitment across political lines will be necessary for any redraft or rewriting to be effective. The committee has recognised that to redraft the act and simplify its administration will not be an easy process, nor will it be quick or inexpensive. Nevertheless, in the committee's view a redraft must be commenced urgently. The committee therefore recommends that sufficient resources be devoted to this exercise as a matter of the highest priority.

I now turn to administrative structures. After 80 years the committee considers the time is now ripe for the establishment of a new administrative framework for the tax office. The committee considered a number of options, including the establishment of a board of management. I might say that Senator Bishop, in a minority report, expressed a preference for a board. However, the committee determined that the Taxation Office should be constituted under its own act as the Australian taxation commission. Through such a commission it was felt that the advantages of a board could be embraced. In addition, a commission would facilitate the use of experts in executive roles on either a full-time or part-time basis. It was also felt that a commission would allow for a more flexible system for the employment of taxation professionals and provide the capacity to respond to changing international and domestic priorities.

The committee has carefully and comprehensively considered the system of private and public rulings issued by the commissioner. The committee has recognised the importance and significance of rulings for taxpayers. As an administrator, the Commissioner of Taxation has no authority to create law. Nevertheless, as a result of both legislative changes and the financial barriers in assessing judicial review, the committee acknowledges that the word of the commissioner has come to be seen by many as de facto or quasi law.

The committee gave extensive consideration to proposals to make the commissioner's rulings subordinate law through the procedures of tabling and disallowance. While this mechanism would provide parliamentary scrutiny and an effective discipline in the exercise of the commissioner's powers and discretions, the committee considered that there were significant practical difficulties in such a system. In particular, the possibilities of delay and increased uncertainty, the need to establish a capacity within the parliament capable of analysing and evaluating technical and complex administrative guidelines, and the capacity of the commissioner to avoid the parliament through an issue of other administrative guidelines were considered to be so significant as to militate against the introduction of such a system.

Nevertheless, the committee has concluded that parliamentary review is both necessary and desirable. The committee has recommended that all public rulings be tabled in the parliament and be available for review by the parliament's committees. In this way, the interpretations, discretions and powers of the commissioner can best be monitored and an effective deterrent to the abuse of power established.

The committee was of the opinion that, to a large extent, public rulings could be construed as delegated legislation—hence, the consideration given to whether they should be just tabled or whether they should be subject to disallowance. In the end, it was decided to recommend that the rulings be tabled in the parliament. I understand that there were 45 rulings last year. The reason the request was made for tabling is that, in the main, neither parliamentarians nor the general public at large have any idea of what rulings are made—they have no idea whatsoever. The committee had the opportunity to recommend that the rulings be made public and, hence, making the taxation commissioner more subject to scrutiny and more accountable to the parliament and thus the people.

Since the introduction of the self-assessment system, the importance of taxation auditing to the detection of taxpayers who fail to comply with the law has been paramount. The powers of taxation auditors to access information are both extensive and exceptional. The committee carefully reviewed the auditing function. Its recommendations for change seek to establish a professional independent audit operation which is balanced and efficient. Through the separation of the information gathering and analysis functions from the decision making process, the committee considers that the powers of the auditors can be better harnessed and the independence of final decisions enhanced.

I turn to the small claims tribunal. There can be little doubt that access to our judicial system has become the privilege of the privileged. It has become so expensive. In the field of taxation this is even more the case as there is no legal aid available to those citizens who wish to challenge the tax office. The committee has recognised this dilemma and urges the establishment of a low cost facility for the resolution of taxation claims below $5,000. While such a facility would not be judicial, it would allow issues of principle and importance to individuals to be argued and settled in a manner which is both practical and equitable. Under the committee's proposal, issues of significance could still be resolved by judicial interpretation where it was considered necessary. However, if the Taxation Office elected to go that route, such determinations would be paid for by the taxpayers and not by the single individual taxpayer.

The committee has evaluated and considered a number of models for a taxpayers' charter of rights. While such statements can satisfy a number of possible goals, the committee concluded that their merit lay in the focus they provided to administration. The committee considered that the extent and description of what constituted a `right' of taxpayers should be detailed in a charter which is readily available for public scrutiny. In addition, the Taxation Office should be required to provide standards of service in accordance with the rights detailed in the charter.

Some other major recommendations in the report include the funding of a taxation ombudsman within the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office, the removal of administrative culpability penalties, the need for a review of the financial position of the Taxation Office and the payment by the Taxation Office of the service fee for lodgment of tax returns on the electronic lodgment service.

In conclusion, while it would always be possible to find examples of deficiencies in any organisation of 18,000 people, the committee recognised that these examples are the exception rather than the rule. Nevertheless, they are exceptions which affect individual taxpayers. The taxation system must be made capable of managing such circumstances.

The report acknowledges that the Taxation Office has been a progressive organisation and generally its management has attempted to produce an efficient public organisation. Thus, while the committee does not condone any inefficiency, it has sought in its 148 recommendations to achieve a structure that will improve the overall administration, reduce costs and provide justice and equity to taxpayers.

I would take this opportunity to thank all the members of the public accounts committee who have participated in the work of the inquiry. In particular, I would like to offer special thanks to Senator Watson and Senator Bishop, who participated in this inquiry from the beginning. I was not on the sectional committee and I only recently became part of the full committee. Hence, one must pay tribute to the incredible amount of work and effort put in by those people over two years to produce this report.

Further, I would like to place on record my appreciation, and I am sure that of all the members of the committee, of the staff of the secretariat of the public accounts committee. I express my sincere gratitude to the committee secretary, Mr Trevor Rowe; to the sectional committee secretaries, Ms Geraldine Skinner and Ms Sue Morton; to the secretariat staff, in particular Mrs Lorraine Brennan and Ms Yolanda Campagna; and to all the other staff members who have spent so many long hours preparing this report.

To the committee's adviser, Mr Simon Edwards, who was seconded to the committee during the inquiry from the Department of Finance, I would like to extend the committee's appreciation for the tireless and professional manner in which he performed his duties. Finally, I would offer the committee's thanks to Mr Peter Dowling, of Ernst and Young in Brisbane, who was engaged in the latter stages of the compilation of the report as a technical consultant to the committee.

I believe this report will provide a platform for a modernised Taxation Office to move into the 21st century as a servant of the Australian people. Like all tax assessments, this report is not all that good and not all that bad. But in view of the incredible amount of evidence and time taken, I believe that in the main it is an excellent report. Nevertheless, there is much to be done in our taxation system to make it better. I believe the expeditious agreement by the government to the adoption of this report's recommendations will be a significant step in the right direction.

By way of a final comment, I would say that the general thrust of the report is to move the balance in a way that is more equitable to the taxpayers than has been the case in the past. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled An assessment of tax and to my minority report attached to it, which I have entitled Tax is inevitable, injustice is not. These reports were tabled in the House of Representatives earlier in the day.

PARA.TAB: My concern about the unequal struggle between the bureaucracy and individual Australians became of vital importance to me during the long inquiry into the MidfordParamount affair, in respect of which we have seen in this last week that the taxpayers have to find $25 million to be paid by way of compensation to the people whose lives, businesses and reputations were ruined by the bureaucracy. It has been a long haul because the government originally opposed my wanting to make that reference to find justice for those people. My motion in this place to have that matter referred to the public accounts committee was vociferously opposed by Senator Button. But at the end of the day this matter was referred to the committee and, with Mr Punch, we worked to find justice for the people who had been destroyed by the actions of the bureaucracy.

When we came to examine the Australian Taxation Office, I was again ever mindful of the fact that there is an unequal struggle between the might of the Taxation Office with its open-ended purse and individual Australians who find that they have no resources to fight back. I have a very high file in my office. I have an agreement from the new Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Carmody, that we will sit down together, now that this report has come down, and go through those complaints by ordinary Australians who find that they have been harshly treated.

I have called my report a minority report as distinct from a dissenting report because its aim is to add things which I thought needed to be dealt with but which were not dealt with in the body of the report, and to flesh out and deal with more fully some items in the main report. Consequently, there is much in the majority report with which I agree and concur but there are other things which I felt needed to be said in the minority report.

There are two important areas where I do, in fact, disagree with the majority report. The first area is the creation of a commission. I have stood in this place too often and heard ministers say, when they are asked questions about bodies which are corporations or indeed commissions, that they cannot and will not answer because they are at arm's length. To me, the Australian Taxation Office must be directly accountable to this parliament. Its officers must appear before estimates committees. There must be a thorough and ongoing accountability to the parliament for the way in which the commissioner exercises the vast amount of discretionary powers that he has under various pieces of legislation.

I have recommended that there be a tax board. A tax board was part of the coalition's policy that we took to the 13 March election. It was a good idea that was properly researched; it is one that I would still continue to support. Therefore, I have said that a taxation board should be appointed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the difference?
—In reply to the minister's interjection, the difference is a question of accountability.
—What is the difference between a commission and a board?

—I am just explaining it to the minister. As I said, a commission is further distanced from accountability to the parliament. So I have recommended that it be a board. Further, I have spelt out the ways in which the board and the commissioner should interact and the accountability that should be directed to the parliament.

PARA.TAB: In the area of rulings there was a further disagreement. I believe that this matter is of paramount importance. Those who read my minority report—and I strongly suggest that people do—will find that one of my major concerns about the manner in which public rulings are made is that they do in fact have the force of law. The commissioner declares that he is actually not making law but, to all intents and purposes, he is. I deal at some length with the constitutional questions that are raised in this respect.

For that reason, I have said and insisted—not only at the end of the inquiry but also during the inquiry—that tabling and disallowance should be applicable to rulings; that, indeed, they should be made in accordance with the ordinary regulation making powers contained within the ordinary taxation legislation. Senator Parer in his tabling address said that the committee was concerned that those rulings should be tabled, but that is merely a method of publishing them. My concern is that the law is made by the parliament. Under our constitution it is the parliament that is required to impose laws.

As honourable senators all remember, we had quite a disagreement with the government over the method of imposing taxation when the question of the budget was being dealt with in this place. Mr Dawkins had wished to place a number of tax impositions and tax cuts in a single omnibus bill, but a committee of this place indicated that it would be likely to be found to be unconstitutional.

Accordingly, I recommend as follows: that the relevant Commonwealth tax acts be amended to provide that general public rulings be issued as regulations under the taxation laws and subject to tabling and disallowance in the parliament to enable persons dissatisfied with a general, that is public, ruling to object to it in the same manner that the legislation now provides for persons to object to a private ruling, and to provide that, where a private ruling applies for more than one year, the acceptance of the private ruling by the person to whom it was issued trigger off the appeal procedure.

There was also a grave concern that with regard to private rulings some may get them and others may not. There is no provision in the present legislation to force a private ruling to be made one way or the other. And of course there is the extraordinary power conferred on the commissioner that he can revoke a private ruling on the basis that he has identified some other group of people that may be affected by the private ruling in a way which he considers to be adverse—a very curious conferring of power.

We go to the question of taxpayers' rights. There was agreement in the committee that taxpayers' rights had to be recognised. Again, that goes to the very heart of the question of justice and equity. At the moment it is a very unfair contest. If we were to use the level playing field terminology we could say that the field is very much tilted in favour of the Taxation Office.

I commend the comments of the majority report on the requirement of a charter of taxpayers' rights, but where I add to the majority report is to say that it should not be a mere statement of platitudes or intentions; it should serve to focus on the discretionary powers vested in the taxation administration and the remedies and safeguards that have been inbuilt to tax legislation to prevent the unauthorised use of such powers. It should also set out the procedures for seeking such remedies.

I therefore make a recommendation that a charter should include, but not be limited to, the rights of taxpayers and the obligations of the Australian Taxation Office during the conduct of an audit—a very important question. Many firms feel that they are put upon by the intrusion of the Taxation Office and very often they will settle those claims on the basis of simply getting them out of their hair. Secondly, there are the procedures by which a taxpayer may appeal an adverse finding by the Australian Taxation Office and, thirdly, there are the procedures that the Australian Taxation Office may use to enforce taxation laws.

The majority report listed the basic entitlements which could be expressed in such a charter. I concur with these points but stress that they do not constitute a comprehensive list of the necessary rights to be recognised. So in the meantime I think it is urgent that we look upon certain sections of the tax act which I think need to be dealt with as a matter of some urgency.

Section 263 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and similar provisions in other taxation laws should be amended to provide that the powers of entry and search only be permitted with a warrant issued by a judicial officer and that the written authorisation carried by the officers of the Commissioner of Taxation attempting to gain entry under section 263 show on its face the premises to be searched and the books, documents and other papers or classes thereof which are the subject of the search, and that the guidelines issued by the Commissioner of Taxation in July 1991 which were concerned with the exercise of powers under section 263 to access documents held on lawyers' premises in circumstances where a claim for legal professional privilege is made be included in the taxation acts of the Commonwealth or in regulations.

I then go on to deal with the highly important question of tax reform and tax law simplification. Two things have occurred. Firstly, the law has become more and more complex because of the way in which legislation is drafted. The technique used is to try to imagine any particular loophole or exception or occurrence that may occur in the future. The result is that we have hugely complicated legislation, the meaning of which is not readily available to or understandable by ordinary Australians—and if the law is not comprehensible, then it is not good law.

So when we talk about the purpose of that legislation, which has been to do away with evasion and avoidance, we also look at the question of simplification. But let me deal first with the question of evasion and avoidance. In the 10 years that Mr Keating has been either Treasurer or Prime Minister, all tax changes or so-called reforms have been brought in to, so-called, get rid of evasion and avoidance. Yet the Auditor-General now qualifies the financial statements of the Australian Taxation Office on the basis that the commissioner has not worked out a means of estimating how much revenue is still being evaded or avoided. The last time he was able to do that was for the 1985 tax summit. After that we have had to rely upon academics and others who are doing their own research and publishing, so that the most recent figure we have is one from an academic, which shows that perhaps the forgone revenue by way of evasion and avoidance is some $6 billion.

To counter this, as I said, the tax gap which has been identified by the Auditor-General and which has resulted in the financial statements of the Australian Taxation Office being qualified for the last several years means that we have no measure, no ready reckoner, of whether or not the laws that are being introduced and administered by the tax act have been effective. So I have made a very strong recommendation that there be an outside review of how we can find a proper way of measuring that tax gap so that we can know whether there is efficiency in the administration of that office.

One will also find in my minority report a detailed analysis of the manner in which Mr Boucher handled the modernisation agreements, both with the finance department and with the Public Sector Union. Those two agreements are in competition with each other. The promises made to the Department of Finance could not be met because of the effect of the Public Sector Union. One will find from the evidence that the Taxation Office was going to be $114 million short over a period of some two to three years; that if it did not get an injection of additional money, that is, $114 million, it was going to be unable to pay the salary bills.

The agreement with the Public Sector Union meant that the Taxation Office could not shed the staff that it was required to do under its agreement with the Department of Finance, in return for which the Department of Finance authorised the Taxation Office to spend $1.2 billion of taxpayers' money to so-called modernise the Taxation Office. That modernisation program can be measured only if we see the sorts of mechanisms put in place that I talk about in the minority report.

As a result of our failure to have that standard by which to measure the Taxation Office, we then looked at, both in evidence to the public accounts committee and in estimates, how effective the various shall we say, profit centres, of the tax office are—that is, the various particular varieties of tax. I think honourable senators will find it interesting to note that the fringe benefits tax, which both the majority report and I recommend should be looked at in terms of being simplified and made more certain, has been one of the few growth areas of taxation revenue. But whether or not that is because more revenue is being collected under existing legislation or whether it is because new fringe benefits were added to the fringe benefits tax is not disclosed in any of the material provided by the Australian Taxation Office.

Also dealt with in my minority report is the infamous black hole in the last budget of Mr Dawkins. After the budget was brought down it was discovered by the opposition that, indeed, there was a hole in the figures provided and that, when supporting documentation was read, one saw that new taxes, withholding taxes, were being foreshadowed for subsequent taxation years. There was also a minute tabled by Mr Boucher showing that he thoroughly supported withholding tax as the strategy to be pursued for the collection of tax to meet revenue targets, and yet he finally backed away from his own recommendations. When questions were asked about that black hole, the provision of the additional $114 million, the fact that that $114 million was needed for salaries to be paid and that, in the space of less than three weeks, $1.7 million was able to be found by way of additional compliance, we found that there were no answers forthcoming, and the reason for that change of mind remains a mystery.

Honourable senators will find that I deal with a number of items relating to the politicisation of the Taxation Office—everything from the special treatment given by the deputy commissioner to Mr Keating over the failure to lodge tax returns, when ordinary Australians were prosecuted for that, to the way the commissioner dealt differently with information sought by the Fitzgerald inquiry and information sought by the WA Inc Royal Commission. Those questions remain unresolved, but the evidence remains on the record.

My main concern in bringing down this report is that we see fairness and equity in the tax system. For that reason, I have also dealt with the question of capital gains tax. It is a discriminatory tax which is now being expanded by the way in which, by public rulings, law is effectively being made. I deal in the minority report with Hepple's case; the comments of the High Court, which said this was a matter for the parliament to fix, not the court; and with the subsequent amendment to the act and the way in which that has failed to fix the problem.

The capital gains tax in terms of revenue that it was originally stated it would meet has not met those targets. But it has been a distorting tax in that, because the family home is exempted, savings have certainly been distorted. One did not have to be very smart to work out that that was going to occur. For that reason, and because it is a de facto wealth tax and a de facto death duties tax in many circumstances, I believe that justice and equity in the tax system would be better served not by taxing the family home—which is anathema to me—but by replacing the capital gains tax with a speculative gains tax.

Questions of revenue that would have to be found certainly can be dealt with by identifying compliance and the tax gap that I have referred to by having a systematic and comprehensive system of indicators so that we can know how well or how badly the Taxation Office is being administered. Mr Carmody is new in the job. He held a press conference this afternoon and he said that he would be reading all of the report. He has said that he will certainly read my minority report.

My overwhelming interest is to see that ordinary Australians get a fair go and are no longer en masse described by the commissioner or his office as being tax cheats. Most ordinary Australians are hard working people who try very hard to comply with all laws. The law is complex as it is, and I am reminded of the fact that when the tax pack was first published, it was intended to mean that more Australians would be able to furnish their own returns but, in fact, what occurred was that the number of Australians who used accountants to furnish their returns went up; one look at that tax pack and it frightened them to death, me included.

As I said, my concern for ordinary individual Australians to have a fair go under the bureaucracy began with the vast injustices that were perpetrated in the Paramount Midford case when reputations, health and businesses were destroyed by the act of the bureaucracy. It was only through individual members of parliament—and I was very pleased to play a part—that it was brought to the attention of the public, the parliament and the government with a recommendation that compensation be paid that we finally saw some justice.

By bringing in a minority report today, I believe that I can help ensure that we see less injustice for ordinary Australians so that we do not see in the area of the Australian Tax Office the sort of injustice that was brought down by the Australian Customs Service.

I say again that there is much in the majority report with which I concur and, indeed, was involved with in gathering evidence during the course of the inquiry, but I also felt that there were extra things that needed to be said. I commend both reports to the general readership but I believe that the two areas where I am in disagreement do need thorough consideration, because tabling and disallowance, and a board and not a commission, is the correct way to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to congratulate Senator Parer on his contribution in presenting the Joint Committee of Public Accounts Report No. 326.

PARA.TAB: Few revenue collecting agencies around the world in recent times have attracted such public attention as the Australian Taxation Office. In recent years both the law and the office itself have undergone enormous changes with implications for both tax officials and taxpayers.

I wish to be associated with the joint committee report No. 326, entitled An Assessment of Tax. This was a report of an inquiry into the Australian Tax Office and although its presentation has taken longer than I would have wished, it is nevertheless an important document. The changes that have been undertaken by the Taxation Office in its reform between the presentation of submissions and hearings reflect to the credit of the Taxation Office because many of the difficult issues were addressed prior to the presentation of this report.

Unfortunately, I have not had quite the input since August when I stepped down from my position as Vice-Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts because of my duties as chair of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. I wish to thank the members of the committee publicly for their unanimous agreement to invite me to have a final input into the draft report. This I did, and I thank the committee for that. Ultimately, while not perfect, it does reflect the many thousands of hours of research, hearings and deliberations that were put into this final report.

I think that without the submissions from outsiders the quality of the report would have been less than it is at present. I wish to thank all those people from the private and public sectors who put so many hours into the manner and the professionalism of their presentations. While naturally not agreeing with every aspect of its contents, I nevertheless believe that it will make an important contribution to the further development of the Taxation Office, to tax administration and, hopefully, to the reform of taxation law.

I also wish to join with my colleague Senator Parer in paying tribute to all those members of the public accounts committee and the secretariat who have worked so hard in terms of the final outcome; it has taken many months to prepare. I particularly draw attention to the contributions of Mrs Laraine Brennan for her typing and secretarial skills, to Mr Simon Edwards, who is from the Department of Finance, for much of the writing of the report, and also to Mr Peter Dowling, a partner of the accountancy firm of Ernst and Young, who acted as both a consultant and a technical adviser to the committee during the finalisation of that report.

I would also like to place on the public record my acknowledgment and deep appreciation to my colleagues both in the parliament and the secretariat for a rather special dinner and the presentation of a signed encomium as a tribute to my 15 years on the public accounts committee. I was deeply moved by both the dinner and the encomium.

I thank Senator Bishop for her remarks about my contribution to her minority report. I think her minority report reflects matters that are of deep importance to Senator Bishop and that she felt compelled to put them on the public record in the way in which she has done. I commend people to read that minority report, which is attached to the end of the major report.

In fact, during the 1960s and 1970s, it is now recognised that there was widespread tax avoidance. In more recent years, the pendulum has swung very much, in fact too much, the other way. I believe that it was the movement of this pendulum that was the essential concern to Senator Bishop throughout the deliberations of the hearings. I think this is reflected in her very thoughtful contribution.

But there is one matter that I must draw attention to that received a great deal of media attention—that is, the vigorous exchange between my colleague Senator Bishop and the Commissioner of Taxation. In fact, one friend of mine suggested that perhaps the title of the report should more appropriately be called `The Bishop and the tax collector' because of that media exchange.

This is an issue that I have thought long and hard about. In considering the very long involvement of the previous commissioner, Mr Boucher, and his leading role in the development of the modern Taxation Office, I do think the report rightly acknowledges that Trevor Boucher was the architect of the modern office and, therefore, he needs that recognition.

Therefore, I think neither the proceedings that took place leading to that report nor the report itself really should contain a reflection or a stain on his character, and I make no apology that I sought to achieve this end. I do not believe that Senator Bishop sought to do that. But, at the same time, as a parliamentarian, I respect her right to ask the sorts of questions that she did; they were pertinent at the time. I think my conduct during the debate adequately reflected that Senator Bishop had the right to ask those questions.

At the same time, I believed that it was important, especially as it was on the eve of Trevor Boucher's retirement, that neither the proceedings could be construed nor should the report be written in such a way that could have reflected to future generations any possibility of stain. Naturally, if there was any reflection, I certainly sought to remove it, and I make no apology for that.

Senator Bishop also had concerns about distancing the commission, as recommended, from the parliament. I would like to think that having had such close parliamentary contact with the Taxation Office, the issues that I hope that I put into the report will ensure that those parliamentary links with the Taxation Office will not only be preserved but also strengthened.

I also draw attention to the enormous amount of time that parliamentarians put into these reports. I think it is important to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that following a long evening—we often had heated exchanges as to how issues should be expressed—my colleague from the House of Representatives Mr Alex Somlyay unfortunately suffered a heart attack. I think it is appropriate that we should place on the record our wish of a speedy and complete recovery from his hospitalisation. I think it reflects the fact that we work hard in this place, that we put in long hours and that from time to time one of the consequences is ill health. I commend you, Mr Acting Deputy President, on the role that you are playing in attempting to have more sensible hours in this place.

While there have been many calls for the rewriting of the tax act, I issue a warning that it is not necessarily the Income Tax Assessment Act but perhaps the Fringe Benefits Tax Act that contains the greatest pitfalls nowadays or the greatest problems for taxpayers. I note my colleague Senator Bishop's comments in this regard. But in all these calls for the rewriting of the tax act, we have to acknowledge that, if the underlying premise is fundamentally wrong, plain English will not solve taxpayers' problems. It will be a complex task, and I urge the involvement of practitioners and academics outside the Taxation Office in that rewriting exercise.

I think that one of the difficulties that taxpayers face nowadays is the failure, perhaps of the Taxation Office, to always acknowledge the important rule of law concept of precedent because without the acceptance of precedent there can be no certainty before the law. I think there are enough cases to indicate, perhaps, a need for a direction to the tax office in upholding this very important concept of precedents.

There is also the other question of the emphasis of audit on grey areas. Certainty before the law is an utmost requirement in any taxation which relies on self-assessment. Therefore, in closing, I commend honourable senators to read the majority report and also the minority report, written by my colleague Senator Bishop. I think both these documents, and the attachments, will reflect significantly the further developments and modernisation of the tax office. I wish tax offices and others who will be involved in this process well.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is addressing the Copyright Amendment (Re-enactment) Bill 1993. The bill, as the name implies, is a re-enactment of the 1989 amendment act, which has become invalid due to a decision by the High Court in May 1993. The provision which was fatal to the whole legislation related to the royalty payable on blank audio tapes. The High Court found the royalty to be a tax and that it therefore violated section 55 of the constitution which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Laws imposing taxation shall only deal with the imposition of taxation and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect.

The provisions of the 1993 bill do not effect any policy change or new initiative. They are directed solely to re-enacting the amendments to the principal act made by the amending act of 1989, with the exception of those imposing, and related to the imposition of, the blank tape royalty. Thus, the amendments propose to do the following: protect performers from unauthorised recording or broadcasting of their live performances; enable educational institutions and institutions assisting the handicapped to copy television programs off air in return for payment to copyright owners; streamline the existing licences to educational institutions for photocopying by abandoning requirements for record keeping and payments for actual copying, and substituting an estimate payment scheme with charges made per student; remove copyright protection for industrially applied artistic works and so remove the duplication of protection under the Designs Act 1906; streamline the existing statutory licence for record manufacture; and make various other miscellaneous amendments primarily of a technical nature, given that the validation will be retrospective and, therefore, the stages of commencement of various parts of the amending act and the actual dates of the deemed commencement of particular sections are already known. The Democrats will be supporting the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Spindler has outlined, the Copyright Amendment (Re-enactment) Bill 1993 simply seeks to validate all those portions of the Copyright Amendment Act that was passed in 1989, except those dealing with the blank tape royalty, which, as Senator Spindler and others pointed out earlier, was held by the High Court to be a tax. As a consequence, the whole bill, in effect, was held to be invalid because taxing bills can deal with only one subject of taxation and they must deal only with the imposition of tax. The blank tape royalty, which was held to be a tax, was so inextricably entwined with the other bits that the whole lot fell. Consequently, for the same reasons as outlined by the Australian Democrats, the coalition supports this bill.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Copyright Amendment (Re-enactment) Bill 1993 is to repeal and re-enact, with retrospective effect, all the provisions of the Copyright Amendment Act 1989 that made amendments to the principal act except those related to the blank tape royalty. The bill is necessary because of the opinion of the Chief General Counsel that the whole of the 1989 act is invalid as a result of the court decision concerning the constitutional invalidity of the blank tape royalty, which was referred to by Senator Spindler and Senator Vanstone.

Clause 11 of the bill is a provision to ensure that regulations made under any invalid provisions are clearly validated. It does so by deeming them to have been made under the authority of the 1993 act but commencing on the dates that the regulations purported to commence. Such regulations include those made in respect of performer protection, provisions for which were included in the 1989 act.

While this had been thought sufficient to protect the validity of the subordinate legislation, it had been overlooked that under sections 135P and 135ZZB, included in new parts VA and VB, provision was made for the declaration of certain collecting societies to be made by the Attorney-General. The respective declarations of the Audio-visual Copyright Society Ltd and the Copyright Agency Limited were published in the government notices section of the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. 24 on 20 June 1990.

Because the bill has not included specific provisions covering these declarations, there may be doubt as to whether they are saved simply by the retrospective enactment of the primary provisions. This proposed amendment remedies this omission and resolves any doubt. It will add a new clause—clause 10A—which states specifically that the declarations made under the retrospective provisions set out in the clause are taken to have been made in the 1993 act but operate from the making of the declarations.

The proposed amendment is thus in the same form as clause 11 of the bill. It refers specifically to the two clauses—135P and 135ZZB—so as to clearly identify the declarations that are the subject of this special provision. TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is the government's main budget bill, dealing with current expenditure—recurrent ordinary services of government. Appropriation Bill (No. 2) is for the capital expenditure requirements of government. Together with the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, those bills constitute the government's budget bills and they appropriate funds for areas of expenditure outlined in the budget.

PARA.TAB: Appropriation Bill (No. 1), the subject of this debate, seeks appropriations from the consolidated revenue fund in 1993-94 of almost $29 billion for the recurrent ordinary services of government. That level of spending represents a 2.6 per cent increase on the previous year's actual expenditure and is 6.3 per cent higher than the appropriation in last year's Appropriation Bill (No. 1).

If one takes out from the appropriation bills the government's outlays for state and territory governments, one finds a much more significant increase in the Commonwealth government's own purpose outlays. Indeed, they would have risen by 7.6 per cent in nominal terms or 4.1 per cent in real terms from last year's budget. That demonstrates yet again the inability of this government to exercise the necessary controls over its own expenditure to work towards a sensible approach to the deficit and to economic and fiscal policy in particular.

What the Commonwealth has done over recent years—this year is no exception—is squeeze very hard on payments to the states; at the same time, it has gone on its merry way, spending without constraint for its own purposes. Although of a minor magnitude, a classic example of the philosophy and the arrogance that underline that is the recent revelations of the Prime Minister's penchant for Thai teak tables at the Lodge and for Gould bird prints in the cabinet room, at an extra cost of $100,000 to Australian taxpayers. There are already 3,000 works of art in the parliament, all of which would very appropriately be able to adorn the cabinet room. It is all part of the approach of this government.

When the proposed taxation and other revenue measures are taken into account—and they are the bills that have all been dealt with in recent weeks—this budget has been an unmitigated disaster for the government, both politically and in simple economic terms. Although Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is the main budget bill, it seeks to appropriate only a relatively small proportion of the government's total expenditure requirements this financial year, namely, $29 billion. That is because most of the expenditure by government is appropriated through other bills, for example, the social security bill and the like. Nevertheless, this bill is an extremely important bill.

This government believes that tax increases are the way to stimulate the economy. That is really what it has done in this budget. It has increased taxes—and I will come back to this in a moment—except for the small cut in personal income tax that has taken effect this week. It is nonsense to suggest, as the government does, that by increasing the overall level of taxation it will stimulate the economy. Economic growth and the related desperately sought employment growth are not advanced by tax rises, yet this budget has attempted to do just that.

The income tax cuts that have taken effect this week range between approximately $8 and $12 a week depending on one's income, and that is provided one has an income of more than $23,000 a year or thereabouts. Low income earners get virtually nothing at all. They will get nothing at all by way of income tax reductions this financial year. They will get a measly, paltry $150 by way of tax rebate which will not be paid for almost another 12 months.

Those income tax reductions will provide Australians with an extra $1.7 billion in their pockets in 1993-94. That will escalate over the next four years by an additional $12 billion or so. That does not sound too bad, does it? But on the other hand, those tax cuts are dwarfed absolutely by the $31.6 billion in additional tax revenue that the government plans to reap from Australians over the next four years. Despite the income tax cuts, over the next four years every Australian will pay an extra $1,800 in tax. Every household will have to pay an additional $5,650 in tax on top of the taxes that they are currently paying.

I remind the Senate that the much vaunted second round of income tax cuts, promised in the One Nation statement in February 1992 and promised at the time of the election, which were to be worth $5.2 billion in 1995-96 have been abandoned. Of course Labor's minor income tax cuts that we have seen this week have been provided to all Australians at a very high price indeed considering the increase in sales tax, fuel tax and wine tax.

The unemployment figures that were announced last week showed another very disturbing result of 11.2 per cent. We are now supposedly, according to the government, two years into an economic recovery, yet unemployment has hovered around 11 per cent for the last 12 months and there are no signs that the unemployment rate will come down in the near future. The very limited economic growth in the economy at the moment is barely sufficient to accommodate new job seekers let alone satisfy the employment needs of the one million Australians already unemployed.

The reports in the press suggesting that the Treasury and the Reserve Bank are forecasting a very low 0.3 per cent growth in GDP for the September quarter have not been refuted. Indeed, in the Senate estimates committee hearings these claims were, if anything, confirmed. That will very likely take our annual growth for the year below the 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 per cent figure forecast at budget time.

The Prime Minister once said so eloquently that if we cannot get four per cent GDP growth then `you might as well give up the game'. He has been Prime Minister for nearly two years now and he has never got within a bull's roar of four per cent economic growth. He should have given up the game long ago and followed his own edict of that time and saved millions of Australian families and businesses from the suffering and hardship that they have endured over recent years and are continuing to endure.

The tragedy of the present situation—and the issue that concerns all Australians—is that this Labor government has nothing to offer Australians to overcome our economic and related problems. The government is directionless and without a coherent policy structure. Worse still, it has clearly run out of both ideas and energy.

The government is rife with splits. We have had a major split between the two main economic ministers, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), in the last couple of weeks over the question of taxes. The Treasurer adamantly said that taxes will not go up and the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, very clearly raised the possibility of future tax increases. It is less than 10 days ago that he said that the government's deficit strategy may involve some revenue increases, though the government will be very cautious about introducing any substantial additional tax increases. By saying that, Finance Minister Willis is quite clearly indicating that the government is certainly contemplating the need for tax increases in the period ahead.

Will spending be cut to make way for the additional spending promises made for the Olympics, labour programs, Mabo and so on? If the government is to stick with its target of reducing the deficit to one per cent of GDP by 1996-97—that one per cent is creeping out, it is already up to 1.2 per cent—how will that target be met unless either expenditure in other areas is cut or taxes increased. It appears highly likely, given the statements of the ministers, that both will occur. So there have been major splits between the fundamental economic ministers. There has been a split over the reform agenda of the government.
I refer the Senate to the report in the Australian Financial Review on Monday of this week which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Major differences within Federal Cabinet over the Government's commitment to economic reform are expected to boil over. . .

This relates to the government's reform of Australia Post. The government wimped out on the necessary reforms to Australia Post. It added to the very strong wait as to the doubts about the government's capacity to follow through on a reform road in terms of micro-economic and structural reform in this country. We all know this reform is absolutely essential and the government has completely lost the stomach for it, if it ever had it.

PARA.TAB: The main person that should be driving that reform, the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, is becoming increasingly isolated within his own ranks. There are increasing doubts being cast about his political judgment and credibility and that augurs ill not just for Mr Dawkins but for government economic policy making.

We are continuing to fall further behind international best practice in many key micro-economic areas. Our waterfront, despite government attempts at reform, is still well off the mark of international comparability. Our shipping and rail systems are inefficient. Our communications reform has proven to be a disaster with the pay TV debacle. Taxation and business regulatory reform is long overdue. This has been talked about for nearly a decade but precious few, if any, advancements of a significant nature have been made. By most standards the cost of compliance in these areas is increasing rather than decreasing.

We have seen splits over industrial relations with the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, being rolled by the trade unions, which were intent on maintaining their power over all necessary and reasonable reform. The industrial relations package, which is being debated at this very moment in the other House, sets the process of reform backwards. It does not take it forward. The package represents the worst of trade union privilege and puts trade unions further above the law. It discriminates against most private sector employees, thwarts freedom of contract in the workplace and leaves those hoping for job prospects to contemplate a permanent future dependent on welfare.

That is the stark choice that the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Evans, put to the nation recently in a very important speech. He said that we have chosen a high level of unemployment—that was the implication of his remarks—because we have not been able to drive the necessary reforms, particularly so far as the labour market is concerned. Whilst that might help people who are lucky enough to maintain their job, it does precious little for those who are unable to find a job or who are squeezed out of the work force as a result of all of those situations. The No.1 issue in Australia is unemployment, yet this government cannot offer any options for dealing with it, let alone finding any solutions. As I said, the industrial relations package is a further nail in the coffin of the unemployed.

We have seen splits on the budget. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister were ambushed by the caucus economic committee. That indefensible budget, to quote the President of the ACTU, Martin Ferguson, had to go through four rewrites before it was eventually passed. That was a classic example of an inept, out of touch party which even turned on itself. We have seen splits in the government over the fundamental issue of health. We have growing questions over the Prime Minister's leadership capacity and judgment. The teak table exercise, the cabinet room prints and the like are testimony to that.
This government, led by a prime minister whose style is becoming increasingly imperious and arrogant, has no motivation to address, let alone fix, Australia's problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator O'Chee says, the Prime Minister is very much adopting a Caligula-type approach to Australia and Australians. When allowance is made for the massive depreciation in the foreign exchange value of the Australian dollar, Australia today is unequivocally worse off in international comparative terms than when this government came to office over a decade ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1993-94, I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter that has been worrying me for some time. In fact, this matter has come to my attention as chairman of the opposition's waste watch committee. From what I have seen, there is something very wrong with Australia's major communication carrier, Telstra, formerly known as Telecom. Over the last six months I have been involved in investigating a number of allegations of malpractice by Telstra which have been made by both former and present employees. In that time I have met personally with a number of individuals who have made these allegations and I am convinced that it is time for a drastic overhaul of the means by which the management of Telstra operates.

PARA.TAB: I have discovered that overtime abuse within Telstra is not uncommon and that such abuse has existed for many years, apparently with the quiet blessing of management. It is abuse which is costing Australian taxpayers millions of dollars. I have also discovered evidence of overtime rorts within Telstra and of Telstra conducting activities which are not only illegal but also are outside the gambit of the Telecommunications Act.

Finally, I have been able to obtain from the chief executive officer of Telstra, Mr Frank Blount, an indication that there are currently 800 employees under scrutiny for travel allowance fraud. However, of those 800 people, Telstra has managed to bring only a mere handful to court. Most of the individuals it has taken to court to date are in fact former employees who have turned whistleblowers in an attempt to highlight the abuse. They are individuals of lesser rank within the organisation, whilst those guilty at a higher level appear to have escaped unscathed.

The pursuit by Telstra of former employees involved in travel allowance fraud is without any particular formula or management protocol. I am aware that a particular employee was let off a fraud of over $100,000, yet others have lost their jobs over fraud involving much lesser figures. Telstra has launched Operation Echo in an attempt to resolve some of these travel allowance fraud issues. According to the response which I received in estimates, Operation Echo has cost over $250,000 since May last year, yet the amount returned to Telstra is pitiful. Much of the problem with travel allowance fraud within Telstra stems from the fact that management has failed to resolve the contentious issue with the union. In effect, Telstra management has not had the courage to confront the union and that failure to reach agreement has cost Australian phone users millions of dollars.

Telstra has admitted, in response to my questions, that under the existing guidelines it is possible for employees to be paid travel allowance even though they may only be 1 1/2 hours away from their home. There have been instances brought to my attention where employees received travel allowance over weekends yet actually returned to their homes in Telstra vehicles over those same weekends. When we add to that rostered days off and long weekends, we can double the amount.

Telstra has gone so far as to admit that in its current guidelines for travel allowance purposes, there is no minimum prescribed distance. I am sure that within Telstra a culture has developed amongst employees in which travel allowance is seen as a legitimate means of increasing income. I would steadfastly argue that no employee should be out of pocket whilst undertaking duties on behalf of their employer away from home, but what we have at Telstra is a system which is open to abuse, which has been abused, which continues to be abused and which has drawn little, if any, action from the Telstra management to resolve the matter.

I mentioned earlier that I had received evidence of overtime abuse within Telstra. In fact, I understand that a report by Detective Sergeant Doug McKinnon and Detective Sergeant Paine of the Australian Federal Police has vindicated those claims and that there has been evidence of Telstra employees receiving unjustified overtime payments, some—I repeat—whilst on sick leave or annual leave.

In mentioning these further abuses, I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate the case of a Mr Geoff Marr. Mr Marr is a former employee of Telstra who has been dismissed over a purported Cabcharge abuse of around $200. There are two points which need to be made at this stage. The first is that Telstra by its own admission has spent over $145,000 pursuing Mr Marr over this Cabcharge abuse of $200. The second is that these allegations of Cabcharge abuse by Telstra management against Mr Marr only came to light after Mr Marr had taken the step of informing management of his concerns regarding overtime abuse within his department. I believe that Telstra has in reality spent around $400,000 pursuing Mr Marr. I believe it has done so in an effort to silence him and to discredit him, because of his claims of management malpractices. As an example of that, under freedom of information he has obtained over 50,000 pages of documented reports that have been put together about his activities.

We must remember that Mr Marr is unique in that he is the only employee that Telstra has chosen to pursue, Australia-wide, for Cabcharge abuse. Yet Telstra records confirm that other employees have used Cabcharge in similar ways to Mr Marr. Those same records show that a Telstra employee, Mr Gary Ryan, and an associate caught a taxi from Melbourne to Sydney at Telstra expense in September-October 1989 because a flight was missed, in preference to attending a social function, and no action was taken. There are two standards which have been adopted by Telstra management, one which applies to employees who toe the line and another which applies to employees who are not prepared to condone abuses of the system.

These allegations are not just my own. In fact, the national freedom of information manager for Telstra, Mr Hedges, appearing at an Administrative Appeals Tribunal hearing under oath gave sworn evidence that Mr Marr's claim of overtime rorting had been completely substantiated.

We should remember that these allegations of Cabcharge abuse against Mr Marr occurred after he had alerted management to the overtime abuse. In fact, there have been serious allegations made in the Industrial Relations Commission by Commissioner Sheather that Telstra has been guilty of manipulating disciplinary tribunals in order to persecute staff. I wish to quote from the transcript of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission hearing before Commissioner Sheather in which the commissioner said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . This document should be released if only to expose the way Telecom manipulates its disciplinary tribunals and the personnel chosen for them.
I seek leave to table a copy of that transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next matter which needs to be raised regarding the attack on Mr Marr relates to a Telstra order for service or local purchase for Cabcharge dockets in October 1989, No. 253397, and the Cabcharge remittance advice for Mr Marr. I have copies of both these documents which I would also seek leave to table.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These documents clearly show that the Cabcharge abuse for which Mr Marr was subsequently dismissed from Telstra was, in fact, authorised by his manager, Mr Les Tod. I cannot accept that an employee can be held responsible when a manager has seen fit to authorise his use of Cabcharge dockets. Further, it took Mr Tod almost nine months to change his mind regarding the validity of those documents—I guess there had been a fair amount of pressure on him to do it—which had been previously authorised.

PARA.TAB: In estimates committee hearings I raised the issue of the use of private investigators by Telstra. At the time, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) indicated some horror that I should suggest that Telstra would be involved in such activities. I have now received an answer from Telstra in which it admits that the firm of private investigators known as John R. Craig and Associates was hired by Telstra to spy on Mr Marr.

What also needs to be understood is that in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission hearing of 3 November last year, it was confirmed that, in compiling the report on Mr Marr on Telstra's behalf, John R. Craig and Associates had—just listen to this—illegally conducted a search of Mr Marr's home and illegally obtained information on motor vehicle registration from the police department and the Roads and Traffic Authority. I have a copy of that information and I seek leave to table it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had fraudulently obtained credit background material relating to Mr Marr by misrepresentation. I have a copy of that information and I seek leave to table it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had illegally obtained information on Mr Marr's police record and had illegally interfered with Mr Marr's mail. Such activities by the private investigators acting on behalf of Telstra were in direct contravention of sections 76D and 5 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914, which deals with illegally obtained confidential information. Yet Telstra not only condoned those activities, but Mr Mark Lillico Thompson, a Telstra employee, authorised payment for those illegal acts conducted on Telstra's behalf.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that Telstra has taken any steps to inform the authorities of the illegal acts undertaken by John R. Craig and Associates on its behalf. In fact, I believe that Telstra continues to use John R. Craig and Associates. It is interesting that the last paragraph of the John R. Craig and Associates report on Mr Marr to Telstra states:

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to other enquiries as requested, we failed to ascertain most information on the grounds of the Privacy Act and our usual sources were reluctant because of the I.C.A.C. enquiry.

The quote clearly shows that not only did Telstra management, and in particular Mr Mark Lillico Thompson, condone these illegal acts; they in fact requested private investigators to conduct illegal acts against a former employee. I believe that the seriousness of these facts is such that they warrant a thorough and detailed investigation of the means by which Telstra operates.

PARA.TAB: If these activities conducted by Telstra were not serious enough, then I believe we need to draw attention again to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission hearing where Mr Mark Lillico Thompson, who is Telstra's legal services officer, on page 196 of the transcript of that hearing admits that two Telstra protective services officers, Mr David Dale and Mr Leigh Rankin, had obtained copies of bank statements which were in Mr Marr's possession, In fact, Mr Lillico Thompson further admits that such documents were on the Telstra protective services file. I have a copy of the document from the file which I seek leave to table. That is document No. 6.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —So we have a situation not only where Telstra has pursued an employee illegally with a private investigator, but it has also had its protective services officers rifle through the private documents of an employee. It is my belief and my understanding that those documents were removed from Mr Marr's briefcase, which was within his office, without his permission. I am concerned that, again, Telstra has failed to act in relation to these wrongdoings by its present employees.

PARA.TAB: Another report from Mr Sean Cromlin, who is Telstra's group manager of the eastern audit region, raised a number of queries regarding the guidelines which apply to Telstra's internal investigations. I seek leave to table those documents because I believe they show that, at best, the guidelines impose very little constraint on the Telstra investigators.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, Telstra was not content with private investigators obtaining personal documents. In addition, Telstra illegally placed recording equipment on Mr Marr's phone at both his place of work and his home. I have documents which relate to this and I seek leave to table them.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Telstra has repeatedly claimed that such connections of CCAE equipment were merely to record the telephone numbers of calls placed by Mr Marr. However, the documents which I have just tabled indicate that a tape of the calls was in existence. I cannot understand why, if we were only talking about the recording of numbers, it would be necessary to involve a tape. Surely a tape implies the recording of conversations.

PARA.TAB: When questioned in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, Telstra claimed that the records relating to the connection of CCAE equipment to Mr Marr's phones were conveniently destroyed. Such action is in direct contravention of Telstra's national procedures manual for call metering and charging. Part 1.8 of that manual dealing with the retention of files indicates that such files are to be kept for a minimum of three years. Yet, in the Marr case, where the files would be crucial in determining the validity or otherwise of the illegal actions undertaken by Telstra, the files have been mysteriously destroyed.

So there we have it—all that fuss and bother to pursue a poor, unfortunate, well-meaning employee who has been accused of misusing a $200-odd Cabcharge docket. All I have in my possession is 50,000 pages, which may have cost up to $400,000. This is not the only case. Others have contacted me about this type of thing—pressure being put on from above. Another case involved a Mr Paul Kelly at Nowra, who turned whistleblower. As thanks for his troubles he is one of the only people who have been accused.

Getting back to Mr Marr, because of all the shenanigans that have been going on, he now finds himself unemployed, with no compensation. He was a previously valued employee who has become the victim of a witch-hunt which has cost hundreds of thousands of dollars over a paltry $200. Telstra has forgotten the rules of natural justice and should make every effort to resolve this issue for Mr Marr. In the short term nothing has been done. I just hope that by putting this on the record today Telstra may look again at his case.

Unfortunately, like many others, Mr Marr has paid a high price for having the courage to come forward. Ten minutes ago I was supposed to be attending a meeting of the Senate select committee on whistleblowing, which the Senate has set up to look at what happens to whistleblowers.
